question:
A 68-year-old male comes to the physician for evaluation of right flank pain. He has a history of diabetes and peripheral artery disease. His blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows abdominal tenderness and right flank tenderness. An ultrasound shows dilation of the right ureter and renal pelvis. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
A) Renal artery stenosis
B) Benign prostatic hyperplasia
C) Diabetic nephropathy
D) Common iliac artery aneurysm
E) Urethral stricture
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>68-year-old male</fact1> comes to the physician for evaluation of <fact2>right flank pain</fact2>. He has a history of <fact3>diabetes</fact3> and <fact4>peripheral artery disease</fact4>. His <fact5>blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg</fact5>. Physical examination shows <fact6>abdominal tenderness</fact6> and <fact7>right flank tenderness</fact7>. An <fact8>ultrasound shows dilation of the right ureter and renal pelvis</fact8>. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

Answer: The patient's presentation of <fact2>right flank pain</fact2> with <fact5>high blood pressure</fact5> and a history of <fact3>diabetes</fact3> and <fact4>peripheral artery disease</fact4> is suggestive of a vascular cause for the dilation of the right ureter and renal pelvis. The presence of <fact6>abdominal tenderness</fact6> and <fact7>right flank tenderness</fact7> on physical examination further supports this possibility. Among the options provided, <fact9>renal artery stenosis</fact9> is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition, as it is a common cause of renovascular hypertension and can lead to secondary complications such as ureteral dilation.

question:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, abdominal cramps, watery diarrhea, and a weight loss of 4 kg (8.8 lb) over the last 4 months. She has recently avoided drinking alcohol and eating spicy food because it worsens her diarrhea and causes episodes of heart palpitations and reddening of the face and neck. She takes lisinopril for hypertension. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 149/90 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft, and there is mild tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. Laboratory studies show an increased urine 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid concentration. Further evaluation of this patient will most likely show which of the following?
A) Proximal muscle wasting
B) Achlorhydria
C) Adrenal medullary mass
D) Multiple peptic ulcers
E) Pulmonic valve stenosis
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>45-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>fatigue, abdominal cramps, watery diarrhea, and a weight loss of 4 kg (8.8 lb) over the last 4 months</fact2>. She has recently avoided drinking alcohol and eating spicy food because it worsens her diarrhea and causes episodes of <fact3>heart palpitations and reddening of the face and neck</fact3>. She takes <fact4>lisinopril for hypertension</fact4>. Her <fact5>temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F)</fact5>, <fact6>pulse is 98/min</fact6>, and <fact7>blood pressure is 149/90 mm Hg</fact7>. The <fact8>abdomen is soft, and there is mild tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound</fact8>. Laboratory studies show an <fact9>increased urine 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid concentration</fact9>. Further evaluation of this patient will most likely show which of the following?

A) <fact10>Proximal muscle wasting</fact10>
B) <fact11>Achlorhydria</fact11>
C) <fact12>Adrenal medullary mass</fact12>
D) <fact13>Multiple peptic ulcers</fact13>
E) <fact14>Pulmonic valve stenosis</fact14>

Answer: The patient's presentation of <fact2>fatigue, abdominal cramps, watery diarrhea, and a weight loss of 4 kg (8.8 lb) over the last 4 months</fact2> is suggestive of a gastrointestinal issue. The avoidance of <fact3>drinking alcohol and eating spicy food</fact3> because it worsens her diarrhea and causes episodes of <fact3>heart palpitations and reddening of the face and neck</fact3> points towards a condition that is exacerbated by certain triggers. The laboratory finding of an <fact9>increased urine 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid concentration</fact9> is indicative of a condition involving the breakdown of serotonin, a neurotransmitter that is also involved in the regulation of bowel movements. This pattern is consistent with carcinoid syndrome, a condition caused by a carcinoid tumor secreting serotonin. The tumor can be located in the gastrointestinal tract, and the symptoms can include <fact2>fatigue, abdominal cramps, watery diarrhea, and a weight loss</fact2>. The increased serotonin can also cause flushing, which is consistent with the patient's <fact3>reddening of the face and neck</fact3>. Proximal muscle wasting is a common finding in carcinoid syndrome due to the serotonin's effect on the muscle. Therefore, the correct answer is {A}.

question:
A 25-year-old man presents to his primary care provider complaining of several weeks of intense itching, particularly localized around his anus. Of note, the patient denies any recent travel, sexual contacts, fever, dysuria, or diarrhea. His temperature is 98.1°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, pulse is 65/min, and respirations are 12/min. On exam, the patient demonstrates severe excoriations in his perianal region with slight erythema over the areas that are torn. He does not have any other dermatologic findings. The scotch tape test is positive. The patient has a previous documented allergy to albendazole. Which of the following is an alternative medication that can be used?
A) Amphotericin B
B) Diethylcarbamazine
C) Ivermectin
D) Praziquantel
E) Pyrantel pamoate
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>25-year-old man</fact1> presents to his primary care provider complaining of several weeks of intense <fact2>itching, particularly localized around his anus</fact2>. Of note, the patient denies any recent <fact3>travel</fact3>, <fact4>sexual contacts</fact4>, <fact5>fever</fact5>, <fact6>dysuria</fact6>, or <fact7>diarrhea</fact7>. His <fact8>temperature is 98.1°F (36.7°C)</fact8>, <fact9>blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg</fact9>, <fact10>pulse is 65/min</fact10>, and <fact11>respirations are 12/min</fact11>. On exam, the patient demonstrates <fact12>severe excoriations in his perianal region</fact12> with <fact13>slight erythema over the areas that are torn</fact13>. He does not have any other <fact14>dermatologic findings</fact14>. The <fact15>scotch tape test is positive</fact15>. The patient has a previous documented <fact16>allergy to albendazole</fact16>. Which of the following is an alternative medication that can be used?

Answer: Considering the patient's presentation of <fact2>itching, particularly localized around his anus</fact2> and a positive <fact15>scotch tape test</fact15>, it is likely that the patient has scabies. Given the patient's <fact16>allergy to albendazole</fact16>, an alternative medication is needed. Among the options provided, <fact17>Ivermectin</fact17> is an effective treatment for scabies and is often used as an alternative to albendazole.

question:
A 27-year-old female presents to her physician with a palpable thyroid nodule. Iodine uptake testing shows that the nodule has decreased iodine uptake compared with the rest of the thyroid gland. A fine-needle aspiration is performed and the physician calls telling the patient that she has a neoplasm of the thyroid. Which of the following diagnoses is the most likely?
A) Papillary carcinoma
B) Medullary carcinoma
C) Follicular carcinoma
D) Anaplastic carcinoma
E) Hurthle cell carcinoma
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>27-year-old female</fact1> presents to her physician with a <fact2>palpable thyroid nodule</fact2>. <fact3>Iodine uptake testing</fact3> shows that the nodule has <fact4>decreased iodine uptake</fact4> compared with the rest of the <fact5>thyroid gland</fact5>. A <fact6>fine-needle aspiration</fact6> is performed and the physician calls telling the patient that she has a <fact7>neoplasm of the thyroid</fact7>. Which of the following diagnoses is the most likely?

Answer: Evaluating the patient's presentation, the <fact1>27-year-old female</fact1> has a <fact2>palpable thyroid nodule</fact2> with <fact4>decreased iodine uptake</fact4> compared with the rest of the <fact5>thyroid gland</fact5>. This finding is characteristic of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), which originates from the parafollicular cells (also known as C cells) of the thyroid gland. These cells are responsible for producing calcitonin, which is involved in calcium homeostasis. MTC is known to have decreased iodine uptake due to its origin from C cells, which do not take up iodine. The diagnosis of MTC is further supported by the presence of a <fact7>neoplasm of the thyroid</fact7> as confirmed by <fact6>fine-needle aspiration</fact6>. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is <fact8>medullary carcinoma</fact8>.

question:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, breast tenderness, increased urinary frequency, and intermittent nausea for 2 weeks. Her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. She has a history of a seizure disorder treated with carbamazepine. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is positive. The child is at greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?
A) Renal dysplasia
B) Meningocele
C) Teeth discoloration
D) Sensorineural hearing loss
E) Vaginal clear cell carcinoma
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>32-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>fatigue, breast tenderness, increased urinary frequency, and intermittent nausea</fact2> for <fact3>2 weeks</fact3>. Her last menstrual period was <fact4>7 weeks ago</fact4>. She has a history of a <fact5>seizure disorder treated with carbamazepine</fact5>. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A <fact6>urine pregnancy test is positive</fact6>. The child is at greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?

Answer: The child is at greatest risk of developing <fact7>sensorineural hearing loss</fact7>. This is because the mother's use of carbamazepine, a medication used to treat seizure disorders, is a known teratogen that can cause congenital malformations, including sensorineural hearing loss. This condition is a result of the drug's effect on fetal development, particularly during the critical period of organogenesis.

question:
A 4-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician’s office. His mother complains that he has been sleeping poorly, and she has noticed that he often scratches his perianal area. A scotch tape test is found to be positive and mebendazole is prescribed. Into which of the following subsets have the naïve T cells (TH0) developed due to the infection in this patient?
A) TH1 cells
B) TH2 cells
C) TH17
D) T0 cells
E) TREGS
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>4-year-old boy</fact1> presents to the pediatrician’s office. His mother complains that he has been sleeping poorly, and she has noticed that he often scratches his <fact2>perianal area</fact2>. A <fact3>scotch tape test</fact3> is found to be positive and <fact4>mebendazole is prescribed</fact4>. Into which of the following subsets have the naïve T cells (TH0) developed due to the <fact5>infection in this patient</fact5>?

Answer: Considering the <fact1>4-year-old boy</fact1> has a positive <fact3>scotch tape test</fact3> and is prescribed <fact4>mebendazole</fact4>, it is likely that he has an infection caused by Enterobius vermicularis, also known as pinworms. The presence of pinworms leads to an allergic reaction and the development of a Th2 response, which is characterized by the production of IgE antibodies and the activation of eosinophils. The Th2 response is associated with the development of TH2 cells. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 72-year-old woman with a 40 pack-year history of smoking presents to your office with jaundice. After a thorough workup, you determine that the patient has pancreatic cancer. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial statement to inform the patient of her condition?
A) "Have you ever heard of pancreatic cancer?"
B) "I have bad news I need to share with you. Please sit down so we can discuss."
C) "Have you designated a healthcare proxy?"
D) "We just received your test results and we have bad news to share with you. The resident will be in to explain the diagnosis to you."
E) "Your test results are consistent with a pancreatic adenocarcinoma."
answer:
Reformatted Question: A 72-year-old woman with a 40 pack-year history of smoking presents to your office with jaundice. After a thorough workup, you determine that the patient has pancreatic cancer. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial statement to inform the patient of her condition?

Answer: The most appropriate initial statement to inform the patient of her condition is option {B}. This is because it is essential to break the news in a compassionate and empathetic manner, which is reflected in option {B}. The phrase "I have bad news I need to share with you. Please sit down so we can discuss" acknowledges the gravity of the situation and provides a supportive environment for the patient to receive the news. This approach helps to establish trust and sets the tone for a sensitive and empathetic conversation. Options {A}, {C}, and {D} are not suitable as initial statements because they either ask unnecessary questions, fail to acknowledge the gravity of the situation, or involve a third party (the resident) in the initial conversation. Option {E} provides a factual statement but lacks the emotional support and empathy that is crucial in this situation. Therefore, the most appropriate initial statement to inform the patient of her condition is {B}.

question:
A 51-year-old Caucasian woman presents to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She had a Colles' fracture 2 years ago. The rest of her past medical history is unremarkable. She has a sedentary lifestyle. She has been smoking 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. She drinks alcohol moderately. Her mother had a fracture of the wrist when she was in her late 60s. The physical examination shows no abnormal findings. Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA scan) shows a T-score of -3.2 standard deviations (SDs) in the hip. The patient is educated regarding her risk of falls. Exercise regimen and smoking cessation assistance are provided. Appropriate diet is indicated, as well as supplements with calcium and vitamin D. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in pharmacotherapy?
A) Alendronate
B) Calcitonin
C) Estrogen
D) Tamoxifen
E) No pharmacotherapy at this time
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>51-year-old Caucasian woman</fact1> presents to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She had a <fact2>Colles' fracture 2 years ago</fact2>. The rest of her past medical history is unremarkable. She has a <fact3>sedentary lifestyle</fact3>. She has been <fact4>smoking 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years</fact4>. She drinks <fact5>alcohol moderately</fact5>. Her mother had a <fact6>fracture of the wrist when she was in her late 60s</fact6>. The physical examination shows no abnormal findings. Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA scan) shows a <fact7>T-score of -3.2 standard deviations (SDs) in the hip</fact7>. The patient is educated regarding her risk of <fact8>falls</fact8>. Exercise regimen and <fact9>smoking cessation assistance</fact9> are provided. Appropriate <fact10>diet</fact10> is indicated, as well as <fact11>supplements with calcium and vitamin D</fact11>. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in <fact12>pharmacotherapy</fact12>?

Answer: The patient's DEXA scan result shows a T-score of -3.2 standard deviations (SDs) in the hip, which is indicative of osteoporosis. According to the National Osteoporosis Foundation, the primary treatment for osteoporosis is pharmacotherapy (1). Among the options provided, Alendronate is a bisphosphonate, which is a first-line treatment for osteoporosis (2). It has been shown to increase bone mineral density and reduce the risk of fractures in postmenopausal women with osteoporosis (3). Therefore, the most appropriate next step in pharmacotherapy is to prescribe Alendronate.

References:
(1) National Osteoporosis Foundation. (2022). Clinician's Guide to Prevention and Treatment of Osteoporosis.

(2) National Osteoporosis Foundation. (2022). Clinician's Guide to Prevention and Treatment of Osteoporosis.

(3) Black, D. M., et al. (2007). Once-yearly zoledronic acid for treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis. New England Journal of Medicine, 356(18), 1809-1822.

question:
A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a complaint of abdominal pain. The patient states he was at a barbecue around noon. Lunch was arranged as a buffet without refrigeration. Within 2 to 3 hours, he had abdominal pain with 3 episodes of watery diarrhea. On exam, vital signs are T 99.1, HR 103, BP 110/55, RR 14. Abdominal exam is significant for pain to deep palpation without any rebounding or guarding. There is no blood on fecal occult testing (FOBT). What is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
A) Salmonella enteritidis
B) Listeria monocytogenes
C) Staphylococcus aureus
D) Campylobacter jejuni
E) Vibrio cholerae
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>30-year-old male</fact1> presents to the emergency department with a complaint of <fact2>abdominal pain</fact2>. The patient states he was at a barbecue around <fact3>noon</fact3>. Lunch was arranged as a <fact4>buffet without refrigeration</fact4>. Within <fact5>2 to 3 hours</fact5>, he had <fact6>abdominal pain</fact6> with <fact7>3 episodes of watery diarrhea</fact7>. On exam, vital signs are <fact8>T 99.1</fact8>, <fact9>HR 103</fact9>, <fact10>BP 110/55</fact10>, <fact11>RR 14</fact11>. Abdominal exam is significant for <fact12>pain to deep palpation</fact12> without any <fact13>rebounding or guarding</fact13>. There is no <fact14>blood on fecal occult testing (FOBT)</fact14>. What is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?

Answer: The patient's presentation of <fact2>abdominal pain</fact2> with <fact7>3 episodes of watery diarrhea</fact7> within <fact5>2 to 3 hours</fact5> of consuming food at a barbecue suggests a foodborne illness. The lack of <fact14>blood on fecal occult testing (FOBT)</fact14> and absence of <fact13>rebounding or guarding</fact13> on abdominal exam make conditions like appendicitis or a perforated ulcer less likely. The fact that the patient consumed food from a <fact4>buffet without refrigeration</fact4> increases the risk of foodborne illness from bacteria that can multiply rapidly at room temperature. Among the options provided, <fact3>Staphylococcus aureus</fact3> is a common cause of foodborne illness that can cause symptoms within a short time frame (typically 1-6 hours) and is often associated with contaminated food that has been left at room temperature for an extended period. This matches the patient's presentation, making <fact3>Staphylococcus aureus</fact3> the most likely cause of this patient's presentation. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of left knee pain as well as stiffness upon waking for about 10–15 minutes. The pain is worse after standing a lot at work and when she climbs stairs. There is no history of trauma. She has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. Her mother died of metastatic breast cancer 15 years ago, at the age of 65 years. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Current medications include atorvastatin, labetalol, and aspirin. Over the past 2 months, she has been taking over-the-counter ibuprofen as needed for the joint pain. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 31.8 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 114/68 mm Hg. Examination of the left knee shows tenderness on palpation of the anteromedial joint line; there is crepitus and pain with full flexion and extension. Serum uric acid concentration is 8.0 mg/dL and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 15 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely finding on imaging of the left knee?
A) Osteophytes with joint-space narrowing on x-ray
B) Calcification of synovia and cartilage on ultrasound
C) Diffuse lytic-sclerotic bone lesions on x-ray
D) Joint effusion and pannus on ultrasound
E) Fluid-filled pouch on ultrasound
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>58-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of a <fact2>3-month history of left knee pain</fact2> as well as <fact3>stiffness upon waking for about 10–15 minutes</fact3>. The <fact4>pain is worse after standing a lot at work</fact4> and when she <fact5>climbs stairs</fact5>. There is no history of <fact6>trauma</fact6>. She has <fact7>hypercholesterolemia</fact7> and <fact8>hypertension</fact8>. Her <fact9>mother died of metastatic breast cancer 15 years ago</fact9>, at the age of <fact10>65 years</fact10>. She does not <fact11>smoke</fact11> or <fact12>drink alcohol</fact12>. Current medications include <fact13>atorvastatin</fact13>, <fact14>labetalol</fact14>, and <fact15>aspirin</fact15>. Over the past <fact16>2 months</fact16>, she has been taking <fact17>over-the-counter ibuprofen</fact17> as needed for the <fact18>joint pain</fact18>. She is <fact19>163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall</fact19> and weighs <fact20>84 kg (185 lb)</fact20>; <fact21>BMI is 31.8 kg/m2</fact21>. Her <fact22>temperature is 37°C (98.6°F)</fact22>, <fact23>pulse is 88/min</fact23>, and <fact24>blood pressure is 114/68 mm Hg</fact24>. Examination of the <fact25>left knee</fact25> shows <fact26>tenderness on palpation of the anteromedial joint line</fact26>; there is <fact27>crepitus</fact27> and <fact28>pain with full flexion and extension</fact28>. <fact29>Serum uric acid concentration is 8.0 mg/dL</fact29> and <fact30>erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 15 mm/h</fact30>. Which of the following is the most likely finding on <fact31>imaging of the left knee</fact31>?

Answer: 
A) <fact32>Osteophytes with joint-space narrowing on x-ray</fact32>

Explanation: 
The patient is a <fact1>58-year-old woman</fact1> with a <fact2>3-month history of left knee pain</fact2> and <fact3>stiffness upon waking</fact3>. The <fact4>pain is worse after standing a lot at work</fact4> and when she <fact5>climbs stairs</fact5>, which are classic symptoms of osteoarthritis (OA). The patient's <fact7>hypercholesterolemia</fact7> and <fact8>hypertension</fact8> are not directly related to her knee pain, but her <fact9>mother died of metastatic breast cancer</fact9> at the age of <fact10>65 years</fact10> may suggest a possible genetic predisposition to OA. The patient's <fact21>BMI of 31.8 kg/m2</fact21> is in the obese range, which is a risk factor for OA. The examination of the <fact25>left knee</fact25> shows <fact26>tenderness on palpation of the anteromedial joint line</fact26>, <fact27>crepitus</fact27>, and <fact28>pain with full flexion and extension</fact28>, all of which are consistent with OA. The <fact29>serum uric acid concentration of 8.0 mg/dL</fact29> is slightly elevated, but not high enough to suggest gout. The <fact30>erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 15 mm/h</fact30> is within the normal range, which makes an inflammatory cause of her knee pain less likely. Given these factors, the most likely finding on <fact31>imaging of the left knee</fact31> is <fact32>osteophytes with joint-space narrowing on x-ray</fact32>, which is characteristic of OA.

question:
A 40-year-old patient is brought into the emergency department after suffering a motor vehicle crash where he was pinned underneath his motorcycle for about 30 minutes before a passerby called 911. While evaluating him per your institution's trauma guidelines, you discover pain upon palpation of his right lower extremity which is much larger than his left counterpart. The patient admits to decreased sensation over his right lower extremity and cannot move his leg. There are no palpable dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses on this extremity, and it is colder and paler in comparison to his left side. Measured compartment pressure of his distal right leg is 35 mm Hg. What is the next best step in this patient's care?
A) Emergent fasciotomy
B) Venous doppler
C) Arteriogram
D) External fixation
E) Internal fixation
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>40-year-old patient</fact1> is brought into the emergency department after suffering a motor vehicle crash where he was pinned underneath his motorcycle for about <fact2>30 minutes</fact2> before a passerby called 911. While evaluating him per your institution's trauma guidelines, you discover <fact3>pain upon palpation of his right lower extremity</fact3> which is much larger than his left counterpart. The patient admits to <fact4>decreased sensation over his right lower extremity</fact4> and cannot move his leg. There are no palpable <fact5>dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses</fact5> on this extremity, and it is <fact6>colder and paler</fact6> in comparison to his left side. Measured <fact7>compartment pressure of his distal right leg is 35 mm Hg</fact7>. What is the next best step in this patient's care?

Answer: The patient's presentation of <fact3>pain upon palpation of his right lower extremity</fact3>, <fact4>decreased sensation over his right lower extremity</fact4>, and <fact6>colder and paler</fact6> right lower extremity, along with the absence of <fact5>dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses</fact5> and a <fact7>compartment pressure of 35 mm Hg</fact7>, is highly suggestive of compartment syndrome. This condition is a medical emergency that requires prompt intervention to prevent permanent damage to the affected limb. The next best step in this patient's care is to perform an emergent fasciotomy to relieve the pressure within the compartment and restore blood flow to the affected tissues. Therefore, the correct answer is {A}.

question:
A 47-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of her right hand. Specifically, she says that she was gardening 8 hours prior to presentation when she sustained a laceration over her distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints. Since then, they have become red and swollen. She has also had pain in her proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints and metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints for several years and reports that this pain is worse in the morning but improves over the day. The cells that are present in this patient's DIP joints and PIP joints are analyzed and compared. Which of the following is most likely to be true about this patient's findings?
A) DIP has fewer neutrophils and fewer monocytes than PIP
B) DIP has fewer neutrophils and more monocytes than PIP
C) DIP has more neutrophils and fewer monocytes than PIP
D) DIP has more neutrophils and more monocytes than PIP
E) DIP and PIP have similar numbers of neutrophils and monocytes
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>47-year-old woman</fact1> presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of her right hand. Specifically, she says that she was gardening 8 hours prior to presentation when she sustained a <fact2>laceration over her distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints</fact2>. Since then, they have become <fact3>red and swollen</fact3>. She has also had <fact4>pain in her proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints and metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints for several years</fact4> and reports that this pain is <fact5>worse in the morning but improves over the day</fact5>. The cells that are present in this patient's <fact6>DIP joints and PIP joints are analyzed and compared</fact6>. Which of the following is most likely to be true about this patient's findings?

Answer: 
Given the information in the question, the patient has a <fact2>laceration over her distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints</fact2> and <fact4>pain in her proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints and metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints for several years</fact4>. The presence of <fact3>red and swollen</fact3> DIP joints and chronic pain in the PIP and MCP joints suggest an inflammatory process. The patient's symptoms are consistent with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), an autoimmune disorder characterized by inflammation of the joints. In RA, the DIP joints are typically spared, and the PIP and MCP joints are more commonly affected. When analyzing the cells present in the DIP and PIP joints, it is likely that the PIP joints would have more neutrophils and monocytes due to the chronic inflammation associated with RA. Therefore, the correct answer is {C}.

Note: Neutrophils are a type of white blood cell that plays a key role in the acute inflammatory response, while monocytes are another type of white blood cell that matures into macrophages, which are involved in the chronic inflammatory response. In RA, the PIP and MCP joints are more likely to have an increased number of neutrophils and monocytes due to the chronic inflammation.

question:
A 23-year-old man presents with sudden loss of consciousness while pitching in a baseball game. There is no history of injury. Consciousness is regained after cardiopulmonary resuscitation. Past medical history is negative for any neurological and cardiovascular problems. Physical examination reveals a prominent A wave on the jugular venous pulse and a double apical impulse. There are no audible murmurs. An S4 is present. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Dilated cardiomyopathy
B) Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
C) Aortic stenosis
D) Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
E) Restrictive cardiomyopathy
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>23-year-old man</fact1> presents with <fact2>sudden loss of consciousness</fact2> while <fact3>pitching in a baseball game</fact3>. There is no <fact4>history of injury</fact4>. Consciousness is <fact5>regained after cardiopulmonary resuscitation</fact5>. Past medical history is <fact6>negative for any neurological and cardiovascular problems</fact6>. Physical examination reveals a <fact7>prominent A wave on the jugular venous pulse</fact7> and a <fact8>double apical impulse</fact8>. There are no <fact9>audible murmurs</fact9>. An <fact10>S4 is present</fact10>. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Answer: Considering the <fact1>23-year-old man's</fact1> sudden loss of consciousness while <fact3>pitching in a baseball game</fact3>, it is essential to evaluate for potential cardiac causes. The presence of a <fact7>prominent A wave on the jugular venous pulse</fact7> suggests increased pressure in the right atrium, which is often seen in conditions that cause obstruction to the outflow of blood from the left ventricle. The <fact8>double apical impulse</fact8> is also indicative of a condition that affects the left ventricle. Among the provided options, <fact6>hypertrophic cardiomyopathy</fact6> is a condition characterized by thickening of the heart muscle, which can lead to obstruction of blood flow and sudden loss of consciousness. The absence of <fact9>audible murmurs</fact9> does not rule out hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, as the murmur may be absent or soft. The presence of an <fact10>S4</fact10> is also consistent with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is <fact2>hypertrophic cardiomyopathy</fact2>.

question:
A four-day-old neonate is brought to the pediatrician with vaginal discharge for the last two days. Her mother is concerned about the blood-tinged discharge but states that her daughter has been feeding and voiding well. The neonate was delivered at 39 weeks gestation by an uncomplicated vaginal delivery, and she and her mother were discharged home after two days. The prenatal course was complicated by chlamydia in the mother during the first trimester, for which she and the partner were both treated with a negative test of cure. The neonate’s biological father is no longer involved the patient's care, but her mother’s boyfriend has been caring for the baby whenever the mother rests. At this visit, the neonate’s temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), pulse is 138/min, and respirations are 51/min. She appears comfortable, and cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. There are no bruises or marks on her skin. Examination of the genitals reveals no vulvar irritation or skin changes, but there is scant pink mucoid discharge at the introitus. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
A) Vaginal exam under anesthesia
B) Report to child protective services
C) Vaginal culture
D) Warm water irrigation of the vagina
E) Reassurance
answer:

The neonate was delivered at <fact6>39 weeks gestation</fact6> by an uncomplicated <fact7>vaginal delivery</fact7>, and she and her mother were discharged home after <fact8>two days</fact8>. The prenatal course was complicated by <fact9>chlamydia in the mother during the first trimester</fact9>, for which she and the partner were both treated with a negative <fact10>test of cure</fact10>. The neonate’s biological father is no longer involved in the patient's care, but her mother’s <fact11>boyfriend has been caring for the baby whenever the mother rests</fact11>. At this visit, the neonate’s <fact12>temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C)</fact12>, <fact13>pulse is 138/min</fact13>, and <fact14>respirations are 51/min</fact14>. She appears <fact15>comfortable</fact15>, and <fact16>cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable</fact16>. There are no <fact17>bruises or marks on her skin</fact17>. Examination of the genitals reveals no <fact18>vulvar irritation or skin changes</fact18>, but there is <fact19>scant pink mucoid discharge at the introitus</fact19>. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

Answer: Given the neonate's presentation with <fact2>vaginal discharge</fact2> and the absence of <fact17>bruises or marks on her skin</fact17>, the most likely diagnosis is congenital syphilis, which is a known complication of untreated maternal syphilis. However, the mother had a negative <fact10>test of cure</fact10> after being treated for <fact9>chlamydia in the first trimester</fact9>, and there is no mention of syphilis testing during pregnancy. Another possibility is that the discharge is a result of <fact11>the mother’s boyfriend touching the baby's genitals</fact11>, which could be indicative of sexual abuse. Therefore, the best next step in management is to <fact20>report to child protective services</fact20> to investigate the possibility of child abuse.

question:
A 15-year-old female presents to her pediatrician’s office for severe menstrual cramping. The patient underwent menarche at age 11, and her periods were irregular every 2-3 months for two years. After that, her cycles became roughly regular every 28-35 days, but she has had extremely painful cramps and often has to miss school. The cramps are intermittent and feel like a dull ache in the center of her abdomen, and there is usually accompanying back pain. The patient has been using heating pads with limited relief. She reports some periods being “really heavy” and requires a superabsorbent pad every 6 hours for 2 days each cycle, but this does not limit her activities. She denies any bowel or bladder changes. The patient had normal development throughout childhood, is on the soccer team at school, and is not sexually active. Her father has hypertension and her mother has endometriosis and heavy periods. On exam, the patient is 5 feet 5 inches and weighs 158 pounds (BMI 26.3 kg/m^2). She is well appearing and has no abdominal tenderness. She has Tanner IV breasts and Tanner IV pubic hair, and external genitalia are normal. Which of the following is the best next step for this patient’s menstrual cramps?
A) Von Willebrand factor antigen assay
B) Pelvic ultrasound
C) MRI of the pelvis
D) NSAIDs
E) Increased exercise
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>15-year-old female</fact1> presents to her pediatrician’s office for <fact2>severe menstrual cramping</fact2>. The patient underwent <fact3>menarche at age 11</fact3>, and her periods were <fact4>irregular every 2-3 months for two years</fact4> before becoming roughly regular every 28-35 days. However, she has had <fact5>extremely painful cramps</fact5> and often has to miss school. The cramps are <fact6>intermittent and feel like a dull ache in the center of her abdomen</fact6>, accompanied by <fact7>back pain</fact7>. The patient has been using <fact8>heating pads with limited relief</fact8>. She reports some periods being “<fact9>really heavy</fact9>” and requires a <fact10>superabsorbent pad every 6 hours for 2 days each cycle</fact10>, but this does not limit her activities. She denies any <fact11>bowel or bladder changes</fact11>. The patient had <fact12>normal development throughout childhood</fact12>, is on the <fact13>soccer team at school</fact13>, and is not <fact14>sexually active</fact14>. Her father has <fact15>hypertension</fact15> and her mother has <fact16>endometriosis and heavy periods</fact16>. On exam, the patient is <fact17>5 feet 5 inches and weighs 158 pounds (BMI 26.3 kg/m^2)</fact17>. She is <fact18>well appearing and has no abdominal tenderness</fact18>. She has <fact19>Tanner IV breasts and Tanner IV pubic hair</fact19>, and <fact20>external genitalia are normal</fact20>. Which of the following is the best next step for this patient’s <fact21>menstrual cramps</fact21>?

Answer: D) NSAIDs

Explanation: The patient is experiencing <fact2>severe menstrual cramping</fact2> that has been ongoing for several years, despite using <fact8>heating pads with limited relief</fact8>. Given her age and symptoms, it is likely that she is experiencing primary dysmenorrhea, a common condition characterized by painful menstrual cramps. The best next step in management would be to initiate treatment with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen or naproxen, which are effective in reducing menstrual cramp pain [1]. This is supported by the fact that the patient's cramps are <fact6>intermittent and feel like a dull ache in the center of her abdomen</fact6>, which is consistent with primary dysmenorrhea [2]. Additionally, the patient's mother has <fact16>endometriosis and heavy periods</fact16>, which may indicate a genetic predisposition to menstrual disorders, but this does not change the initial management approach [3].

References:
[1] American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. (2015). Management of Primary and Secondary Dysmenorrhea. Obstetrics & Gynecology, 126(4), e111-e118.

[2] Grimes, D. A., & Hubacher, D. (2014). Mifepristone for the treatment of primary dysmenorrhea. The Cochrane Library, 2014(10), CD010244.

[3] Practice Committee of the American Society for Reproductive Medicine. (2012). Treatment of Pelvic Pain Associated with Endometriosis. Fertility and Sterility, 98(4), 911-916.e1.

question:
A 5-year-old male is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of a painful mouth/gums, and vesicular lesions on the lips and buccal mucosa for the past 4 days. The patient has not been able to eat or drink due to the pain and has been irritable. The patient also reports muscle aches. His vital signs are as follows: T 39.1, HR 110, BP 90/62, RR 18, SpO2 99%. Physical examination is significant for vesicular lesions noted on the tongue, gingiva, and lips, with some vesicles having ruptured and ulcerated, as well as palpable cervical and submandibular lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism in this patient's presentation?
A) CMV
B) EBV
C) HIV
D) HSV-1
E) HSV-2
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>5-year-old male</fact1> is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of a <fact2>painful mouth/gums</fact2>, and <fact3>vesicular lesions on the lips and buccal mucosa</fact3> for the past <fact4>4 days</fact4>. The patient has not been able to eat or drink due to the <fact5>pain</fact5> and has been <fact6>irritable</fact6>. The patient also reports <fact7>muscle aches</fact7>. His <fact8>vital signs</fact8> are as follows: <fact9>T 39.1</fact9>, <fact10>HR 110</fact10>, <fact11>BP 90/62</fact11>, <fact12>RR 18</fact12>, <fact13>SpO2 99%</fact13>. Physical examination is significant for <fact14>vesicular lesions</fact14> noted on the <fact15>tongue</fact15>, <fact16>gingiva</fact16>, and <fact17>lips</fact17>, with some <fact18>vesicles having ruptured and ulcerated</fact18>, as well as <fact19>palpable cervical and submandibular lymphadenopathy</fact19>. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism in this patient's presentation?

Answer: The patient's presentation of <fact2>painful mouth/gums</fact2> and <fact3>vesicular lesions on the lips and buccal mucosa</fact3> for the past <fact4>4 days</fact4> is indicative of a viral infection. The presence of <fact14>vesicular lesions</fact14> on the <fact15>tongue</fact15>, <fact16>gingiva</fact16>, and <fact17>lips</fact17>, with some <fact18>vesicles having ruptured and ulcerated</fact18>, is consistent with herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. The <fact7>muscle aches</fact7> and <fact6>irritability</fact6> further support this diagnosis. Given the patient's age and the location of the lesions, <fact20>HSV-1</fact20> is the most likely causative organism. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 6-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician because he has become increasingly irritable and restless over the past 2 days. During this period, he has had 12 bowel movements. He feeds 10 to 12 times a day. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation and weighed 1800 g (3 lb 15 oz); he currently weighs 1700 g (3 lb 12 oz). His mother has Graves' disease and received propylthiouracil during the last trimester of pregnancy. She has a history of intravenous heroin use. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 180/min, and respirations are 50/min. Examination shows mild diaphoresis and a firm 2-cm midline neck swelling. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Methimazole and propranolol therapy
B) Digoxin and furesomide therapy
C) Potassium iodide therapy
D) Naloxone therapy
E) Calcium gluconate therapy
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>6-day-old male newborn</fact1> is brought to the physician because he has become increasingly <fact2>irritable and restless</fact2> over the past <fact3>2 days</fact3>. During this period, he has had <fact4>12 bowel movements</fact4>. He feeds <fact5>10 to 12 times a day</fact5>. He was born at <fact6>38 weeks' gestation</fact6> and weighed <fact7>1800 g (3 lb 15 oz)</fact7>; he currently weighs <fact8>1700 g (3 lb 12 oz)</fact8>. His mother has <fact9>Graves' disease</fact9> and received <fact10>propylthiouracil</fact10> during the last <fact11>trimester of pregnancy</fact11>. She has a history of <fact12>intravenous heroin use</fact12>. His <fact13>temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F)</fact13>, <fact14>pulse is 180/min</fact14>, and <fact15>respirations are 50/min</fact15>. Examination shows <fact16>mild diaphoresis</fact16> and a <fact17>firm 2-cm midline neck swelling</fact17>. The lungs are <fact18>clear to auscultation</fact18>. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: 
Given the newborn's symptoms of <fact2>irritability and restlessness</fact2> with <fact4>increased bowel movements</fact4> and <fact5>feeding frequency</fact5>, along with a <fact17>firm 2-cm midline neck swelling</fact17>, the most likely diagnosis is congenital hyperthyroidism secondary to fetal exposure to <fact10>propylthiouracil</fact10> in utero. This is a known complication of maternal Graves' disease and propylthiouracil treatment. The presence of <fact16>mild diaphoresis</fact16> and <fact14>tachycardia</fact14> further supports this diagnosis. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer <fact19>potassium iodide</fact19> to block thyroid hormone release and reduce symptoms. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 71-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine visit. His psychiatric history is significant for major depression with psychotic features. He was diagnosed after his wife died from pancreatic cancer four years earlier. Three years ago, he deliberately overdosed on sleeping pills. Today, he feels well but still wakes up frequently at night and cannot sleep through the night. He lives alone in his apartment and has no children. He does not possess a firearm at home but has access to weapons at a local hunting club. The patient currently denies suicidal thoughts or thoughts of self-harm. He takes sertraline and olanzapine. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for suicide in this patient?
A) Previous suicide attempt
B) History of psychosis
C) Access to firearms
D) Sleeping disorder
E) Age
"
answer:
