There is <fact13>slight tenderness to deep palpation of the mass</fact13>. There is no <fact14>axillary lymphadenopathy on either side</fact14>. Which of the following is the most likely outcome of this patient’s condition?

Answer: D) This mass will most likely decrease in size or disappear over time.

Explanation: The patient is a <fact1>16-year-old female</fact1> presenting with a <fact2>round lump in her left breast</fact2> that has been <fact3>present for 2 months</fact3>. The lump is <fact4>mobile and painless</fact4> and has not caused any <fact6>discharge or skin changes</fact6>. The patient's <fact7>grandmother was diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast</fact7>, but there is no indication that the patient has a family history of breast cancer. The patient is an <fact8>avid softball player</fact8> and denies any <fact9>substances that could potentially increase her risk of breast cancer</fact9>. The breasts appear <fact10>symmetric and normal</fact10> on examination, and the <fact11>3-cm round, mobile mass</fact11> is located in the <fact12>upper outer quadrant of the left breast</fact12>. There is <fact13>slight tenderness to deep palpation of the mass</fact13>, but no <fact14>axillary lymphadenopathy on either side</fact14>. Given these factors, the most likely outcome of this patient’s condition is that the mass will most likely decrease in size or disappear over time. This is because the patient is a young female presenting with a mobile, painless lump in her breast, which is most likely a <fact15>fibroadenoma</fact15>, a common benign breast tumor that often decreases in size or disappears over time.

question:
An unresponsive 92-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance and is quickly followed by his grand-daughter. Approx. 1 month ago, he had a radical prostatectomy, pelvic radiation, and several rounds of chemotherapy for aggressive prostate cancer in Nicaragua and was discharged from the hospital with a suprapelvic catheter and a plan for more chemotherapy. He was coming to the United States to spend time with some extended family. According to the grand-daughter his mental status was altered upon arrival and his health began to decline. She is not aware of his past medical status or medications. At the hospital, his blood pressure is 98/60 mm Hg, the pulse id 110/min, the respiratory rate is 21/min, and the temperature is 35.6°C (96.1°F). On physical exam, the patient appears cachectic, drowsy, and only responds to questions by nodding his head. His heart rate is tachycardic with a regular rhythm and his lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. The cystotomy incision for his suprapelvic catheter is red and swollen. The patient admitted to the hospital and stabilized and started on broad-spectrum antibiotics. The catheter tube produces no urine over 24 hours and only thick green-white puss can be expressed. The treatment team concludes this patient has urinary tract obstruction. What is the best method to evaluate urinary tract obstruction in this patient?
A) Renal biopsy
B) Ultrasound
C) Abdominal-pelvic CT scan
D) Blood analysis
E) Urine analysis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>92-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency department with <fact2>altered mental status</fact2> and a <fact3>decline in health</fact3> after <fact4>radical prostatectomy, pelvic radiation, and several rounds of chemotherapy</fact4> for <fact5>aggressive prostate cancer</fact5> 1 month ago. He is <fact6>cachectic, drowsy, and only responds to questions by nodding his head</fact6>. His <fact7>heart rate is tachycardic</fact7> with a regular rhythm and his <fact8>lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally</fact8>. The <fact9>cystotomy incision for his suprapelvic catheter is red and swollen</fact9> and the catheter tube produces <fact10>no urine over 24 hours</fact10> and only <fact11>thick green-white puss can be expressed</fact11>. The treatment team concludes this patient has <fact12>urinary tract obstruction</fact12>. What is the best method to evaluate <fact12>urinary tract obstruction</fact12> in this patient?

Answer: 
Given the patient's presentation with <fact10>no urine output over 24 hours</fact10> and <fact11>thick green-white puss</fact11> from the catheter tube, it is essential to evaluate the urinary tract obstruction. The best method to evaluate urinary tract obstruction in this patient is <fact13>ultrasound</fact13>. 

This is because the patient has a <fact9>cystotomy incision for his suprapelvic catheter</fact9>, which indicates that the urinary tract obstruction is likely related to the catheter or the surrounding tissues. Ultrasound is a non-invasive imaging modality that can provide valuable information about the urinary tract, including the location and severity of the obstruction. It can also help identify any complications such as <fact11>thick green-white puss</fact11> or <fact7>tachycardia</fact7>. 

Furthermore, ultrasound is a safe and effective method for evaluating urinary tract obstruction in patients with <fact6>cachectic, drowsy, and only responds to questions by nodding his head</fact6>, as it does not require sedation or other invasive procedures. 

In contrast, <fact14>renal biopsy</fact14> is an invasive procedure that carries a risk of bleeding and infection, and is not typically used to evaluate urinary tract obstruction. <fact15>Abdominal-pelvic CT scan</fact15> is a more detailed imaging modality that can provide information about the urinary tract, but it is not necessary in this case as the patient's presentation is consistent with urinary tract obstruction. <fact16>Blood analysis</fact16> and <fact17>urine analysis</fact17> can provide information about the patient's overall health and the presence of infection, but they are not the best method to evaluate urinary tract obstruction.

question:
A 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with constant abdominal pain over the past 8 hours. The pain is in her right lower quadrant (RLQ), which is also where it began. She has had no nausea or vomiting despite eating a snack 2 hours ago. She had a similar episode last month which resolved on its own. Her menstrual cycles are 28–30 days apart with 3–5 days of vaginal bleeding. Her last menses ended 9 days ago. Her blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg, the pulse is 78/min, the respirations are 15/min, and the temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F). Abdominal examination shows moderate pain on direct pressure over the RLQ which decreases with the release of pressure. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 12.5 mg/dL
Leukocyte count 6000/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 55%
Lymphocytes 39%
Platelet count 260,000/mm3
Serum  
C-reactive protein 5 mg/L (N < 8 mg/L)
Urine  
RBC 1-2 phf
WBC None
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Methotrexate
B) Nitrofurantoin
C) Reassurance
D) Referral for surgery
E) Tamsulosin
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>16-year-old girl</fact1> is brought to the emergency department with <fact2>constant abdominal pain</fact2> over the past <fact3>8 hours</fact3> in her <fact4>right lower quadrant (RLQ)</fact4>, which is also where it began. She has had no <fact5>nausea or vomiting</fact5> despite eating a <fact6>snack 2 hours ago</fact6>. She had a similar episode last month which resolved on its own. Her <fact7>menstrual cycles</fact7> are <fact8>28–30 days apart</fact8> with <fact9>3–5 days of vaginal bleeding</fact9>. Her last <fact10>menses ended 9 days ago</fact10>. Her <fact11>blood pressure</fact11> is <fact12>125/75 mm Hg</fact12>, the <fact13>pulse</fact13> is <fact14>78/min</fact14>, the <fact15>respirations</fact15> are <fact16>15/min</fact16>, and the <fact17>temperature</fact17> is <fact18>37.2°C (99.0°F)</fact18>. Abdominal examination shows <fact19>moderate pain on direct pressure over the RLQ</fact19> which decreases with the release of pressure. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: <fact20>Hemoglobin 12.5 mg/dL</fact20>, <fact21>Leukocyte count 6000/mm3</fact21>, <fact22>Segmented neutrophils 55%</fact22>, <fact23>Lymphocytes 39%</fact23>, <fact24>Platelet count 260,000/mm3</fact24>, <fact25>Serum C-reactive protein 5 mg/L (N < 8 mg/L)</fact25>, <fact26>Urine RBC 1-2 phf</fact26>, <fact27>WBC None</fact27>. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Methotrexate
B) Nitrofurantoin
C) Reassurance
D) Referral for surgery
E) Tamsulosin

Answer: C) Reassurance

Explanation: The patient is a <fact1>16-year-old girl</fact1> with <fact2>constant abdominal pain</fact2> in her <fact4>right lower quadrant (RLQ)</fact4> that began <fact3>8 hours</fact3> ago. She has had no <fact5>nausea or vomiting</fact5> and the pain decreases with the release of pressure. Laboratory studies show a <fact21>normal leukocyte count</fact21> and <fact25>low C-reactive protein</fact25>, indicating a low likelihood of infection. The patient's <fact7>menstrual cycles</fact7> are regular and her <fact10>last menses ended 9 days ago</fact10>, which makes it less likely that the pain is related to an ectopic pregnancy. Given these factors, the most appropriate next step in management is <fact6>reassurance</fact6> and possibly a <fact19>follow-up appointment</fact19> to monitor the patient's condition.

question:
A 46-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision where he was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is unconscious. His respirations are 24/min, and palpable systolic blood pressure is 60 mm Hg, and pulse is 141/min and irregularly irregular. Examination shows multiple ecchymoses over the chest. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration over the abdomen and a 4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over the scalp. Jugular venous pressure is increased. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft. Two large bore intravenous catheters are inserted and 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) is negative. An electrocardiogram shows absent p-waves. After 5 minutes, his pulse is 160/min and palpable systolic blood pressure is 50 mm Hg. Vasopressors are administered. One hour later, the patient dies. Which of the following was the most likely diagnosis?
A) Cardiac contusion
B) Hemothorax
C) Aortic dissection
D) Pulmonary contusion
E) Cardiac tamponade
"
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>46-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency department <fact2>15 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision</fact2> where he was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is <fact3>unconscious</fact3>. His <fact4>respirations are 24/min</fact4>, and <fact5>palpable systolic blood pressure is 60 mm Hg</fact5>, and <fact6>pulse is 141/min and irregularly irregular</fact6>. Examination shows <fact7>multiple ecchymoses over the chest</fact7>. There is a <fact8>3-cm (1.2-in) laceration over the abdomen</fact8> and a <fact9>4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over the scalp</fact9>. <fact10>Jugular venous pressure is increased</fact10>. <fact11>Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases</fact11>. Cardiac examination shows no <fact12>murmurs, rubs, or gallops</fact12>. The <fact13>abdomen is soft</fact13>. Two large bore intravenous catheters are inserted and <fact14>0.9% saline infusion is begun</fact14>. <fact15>FAST is negative</fact15>. An <fact16>electrocardiogram shows absent p-waves</fact16>. After <fact17>5 minutes</fact17>, his <fact18>pulse is 160/min</fact18> and <fact19>palpable systolic blood pressure is 50 mm Hg</fact19>. <fact20>Vasopressors are administered</fact20>. One hour later, the patient dies. Which of the following was the most likely diagnosis?

Answer: 
The patient's presentation and progression of symptoms indicate a severe and life-threatening condition. The key findings include <fact3>unconsciousness</fact3>, <fact4>low blood pressure</fact5>, <fact6>irregular pulse</fact6>, <fact10>increased jugular venous pressure</fact10>, <fact11>bilateral crackles at the lung bases</fact11>, and <fact16>absent p-waves on the electrocardiogram</fact16>. These symptoms are consistent with cardiac tamponade, a condition where fluid accumulates in the pericardial sac, compressing the heart and impeding its ability to pump blood effectively. The absence of <fact12>murmurs, rubs, or gallops</fact12> on cardiac examination and the <fact13>soft abdomen</fact13> suggest that the primary issue is not with the heart valves or the abdominal organs, respectively. The <fact15>negative FAST</fact15> also rules out free fluid in the abdominal cavity, which could be indicative of a hemorrhage. The administration of <fact20>vasopressors</fact20> to support blood pressure further supports the diagnosis of a cardiac-related issue. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is cardiac tamponade.

question:
A 7-year-old boy is rushed to the emergency room after losing consciousness 30 mins ago at home. The patient’s mother says that he has had a “running nose” for the past few days However, he did not receive any treatment for it, and his condition rapidly worsened today. He does not have any significant past medical history. His vaccination records are up to date. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.7°F), blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg, heart rate is 120/min, and respiratory rate is 22/min. On physical examination, the patient is unresponsive. There is a petechial rash present on his chest, and he has some neck rigidity. Empiric intravenous antibiotics are started, and a lumbar puncture is performed. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s low blood pressure?
A) Miliary tuberculosis
B) Human immunodeficiency virus infection
C) Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
D) Adrenocortical insufficiency
E) Pheochromocytoma
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>7-year-old boy</fact1> is rushed to the emergency room after losing consciousness <fact2>30 minutes ago</fact2> at home. The patient’s mother says that he has had a “<fact3>running nose</fact3>” for the past few days, but he did not receive any treatment for it, and his condition rapidly worsened today. He does not have any significant <fact4>past medical history</fact4>. His <fact5>vaccination records</fact5> are up to date. His <fact6>temperature is 38.2°C (100.7°F)</fact6>, <fact7>blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg</fact7>, <fact8>heart rate is 120/min</fact8>, and <fact9>respiratory rate is 22/min</fact9>. On physical examination, the patient is <fact10>unresponsive</fact10>. There is a <fact11>petechial rash</fact11> present on his chest, and he has some <fact12>neck rigidity</fact12>. Empiric intravenous antibiotics are started, and a <fact13>lumbar puncture</fact13> is performed. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s <fact14>low blood pressure</fact14>?

Answer: The patient's presentation, including <fact10>unresponsiveness</fact10>, <fact11>petechial rash</fact11>, and <fact12>neck rigidity</fact12>, is highly suggestive of meningitis, a severe infection of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. The <fact3>running nose</fact3> for the past few days, followed by rapid deterioration, could be indicative of a viral or bacterial infection progressing to meningitis. Given the patient's <fact5>vaccination records</fact5> are up to date, the likelihood of a vaccine-preventable disease causing meningitis is low. Among the options provided, <fact4>adrenocortical insufficiency</fact4> (D) is not directly related to meningitis. The other options are not directly related to the patient's presentation or the scenario described. However, one option is related to the patient's low blood pressure. The patient's <fact7>low blood pressure</fact7> could be related to <fact4>adrenocortical insufficiency</fact4> (D) due to the fact that the patient is <fact10>unresponsive</fact10> and has a <fact11>petechial rash</fact11> and <fact12>neck rigidity</fact12> which can be indicative of severe infection and adrenal insufficiency.

question:
A 38-year-old woman is being evaluated by her primary care physician for chronic, widespread pain that started around 5 months ago. This pain has been accompanied by sleeping issues. Her friend recommended that she try yoga to relieve the pain, but she says this has not helped her at all. Se says the symptoms have begun to impact her daily functions and keep her from doing things she used to enjoy. Past medical history includes generalized anxiety disorder, for which she currently takes no medication. The patient had been previously medicated with paroxetine for 5 years. On physical examination, several areas of point tenderness are found on the occipital region, elbows, and medial surface of both knees. Laboratory work up is unremarkable. What is the best treatment option for the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A) Low-dose prednisolone
B) High-dose prednisolone
C) Paroxetine
D) Allopurinol
E) Gabapentin
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>38-year-old woman</fact1> is being evaluated by her primary care physician for <fact2>chronic, widespread pain</fact2> that started around <fact3>5 months ago</fact3>. This pain has been accompanied by <fact4>sleeping issues</fact4>. Her friend recommended that she try <fact5>yoga to relieve the pain</fact5>, but she says this has not helped her at all. She says the symptoms have begun to impact her <fact6>daily functions</fact6> and keep her from doing things she used to enjoy. Past medical history includes <fact7>generalized anxiety disorder</fact7>, for which she currently takes no medication. The patient had been previously medicated with <fact8>paroxetine for 5 years</fact8>. On physical examination, several areas of <fact9>point tenderness</fact9> are found on the <fact10>occipital region</fact10>, <fact11>elbows</fact11>, and <fact12>medial surface of both knees</fact12>. Laboratory work up is <fact13>unremarkable</fact13>. What is the best treatment option for the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Answer: 
The patient's presentation of <fact2>chronic, widespread pain</fact2> accompanied by <fact4>sleeping issues</fact4> and <fact9>point tenderness</fact9> on the <fact10>occipital region</fact10>, <fact11>elbows</fact11>, and <fact12>medial surface of both knees</fact12> is suggestive of fibromyalgia. This condition is characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. The patient's past medical history of <fact7>generalized anxiety disorder</fact7> and previous treatment with <fact8>paroxetine for 5 years</fact8> may be relevant, but the current presentation is more indicative of fibromyalgia. The best treatment option for fibromyalgia typically involves a combination of pharmacological and non-pharmacological interventions. Among the provided options, <fact14>gabapentin</fact14> is a medication that has been used off-label to treat fibromyalgia due to its ability to modulate pain perception. Therefore, the best treatment option for the most likely diagnosis in this patient is {E}.

question:
A 35-year-old female is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious. The patient is found to have a blood glucose level of 35 mg/dL. Hgb A1c was found to be 5.1%. C-peptide level was found to be decreased. The patient returned to her baseline after glucose replacement. She states that she has never had an episode like this before. She has no significant past medical history but reports a family history of diabetes in her mother. She states that she has been undergoing a difficult divorce over the past few months. What is the likely cause of this patient's condition?
A) Insulinoma
B) Factitious disorder
C) Alimentary hypogylcemia
D) Hypothyroidism
E) Somatization disorder
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>35-year-old female</fact1> is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious. The patient is found to have a <fact2>blood glucose level of 35 mg/dL</fact2>. <fact3>Hgb A1c was found to be 5.1%</fact3>. <fact4>C-peptide level was found to be decreased</fact4>. The patient returned to her baseline after glucose replacement. She states that she has never had an episode like this before. She has no significant past medical history but reports a <fact5>family history of diabetes in her mother</fact5>. She states that she has been undergoing a <fact6>difficult divorce over the past few months</fact6>. What is the likely cause of this patient's condition?

Relevant Key Phrases: 
1. <fact2>blood glucose level of 35 mg/dL</fact2>
2. <fact4>C-peptide level was found to be decreased</fact4>
3. <fact5>family history of diabetes in her mother</fact5>
4. <fact6>difficult divorce over the past few months</fact6>

Answer:
The patient's <fact2>blood glucose level of 35 mg/dL</fact2> indicates hypoglycemia, which is further supported by the patient's return to baseline after glucose replacement. The decreased <fact4>C-peptide level</fact4> suggests that the hypoglycemia was not caused by an excess of insulin production, as seen in insulinomas. The patient's <fact5>family history of diabetes in her mother</fact5> is not directly relevant to the patient's acute presentation of hypoglycemia. However, the patient's <fact6>difficult divorce over the past few months</fact6> is a significant stressor that could lead to factitious disorder, also known as Munchausen syndrome. In factitious disorder, an individual fabricates or induces illness in themselves for attention and sympathy. The patient's presentation of hypoglycemia, which was not caused by an underlying medical condition, and the absence of any significant past medical history, suggest that the patient may have fabricated her illness. Therefore, the likely cause of this patient's condition is <fact7>factitious disorder</fact7>.

question:
A 70-year-old obese male presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath and cough of sudden onset. The patient states that his symptoms came on while he was sleeping. The patient has a past medical history of type II diabetes and is currently taking lisinopril, metformin, insulin, and fish oil. On physical exam, you note bipedal edema and jugular venous distention (JVD). An EKG and chest radiographs are obtained (Figures A and B). The patient is started on BIPAP and medical therapy and his symptoms improve rapidly. Lab values are as follows.

Serum:
Na+: 137 mEq/L
K+: 3.2 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
HCO3-: 31 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Glucose: 120 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL
Ca2+: 10.9 mg/dL

Which of the following is the best explanation of this patient's current presentation?
A) Furosemide
B) Hydrochlorothiazide
C) Renal tubular acidosis type I
D) Renal tubular acidosis type II
E) Renal tubular acidosis type IV
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>70-year-old obese male</fact1> presents to the emergency department with <fact2>shortness of breath and cough of sudden onset</fact2>. The patient states that his symptoms came on while he was sleeping. The patient has a past medical history of <fact3>type II diabetes</fact3> and is currently taking <fact4>lisinopril, metformin, insulin, and fish oil</fact4>. On physical exam, you note <fact5>bipedal edema</fact5> and <fact6>jugular venous distention (JVD)</fact6>. An <fact7>EKG and chest radiographs are obtained (Figures A and B)</fact7>. The patient is started on <fact8>BIPAP and medical therapy</fact8> and his symptoms improve rapidly. Lab values are as follows.

Serum:
Na+: <fact9>137 mEq/L</fact9>
K+: <fact10>3.2 mEq/L</fact10>
Cl-: <fact11>100 mEq/L</fact11>
HCO3-: <fact12>31 mEq/L</fact12>
BUN: <fact13>20 mg/dL</fact13>
Glucose: <fact14>120 mg/dL</fact14>
Creatinine: <fact15>1.2 mg/dL</fact15>
Ca2+: <fact16>10.9 mg/dL</fact16>

Which of the following is the best explanation of this patient's current presentation?

Answer: Based on the patient's presentation of <fact2>shortness of breath and cough of sudden onset</fact2> with <fact5>bipedal edema</fact5> and <fact6>jugular venous distention (JVD)</fact6>, it is likely that the patient is experiencing acute heart failure. The lab values show a slightly elevated <fact15>creatinine level</fact15> and a <fact14>glucose level of 120 mg/dL</fact14>, which is slightly elevated but not indicative of diabetic ketoacidosis. The patient's symptoms improved rapidly with <fact8>BIPAP and medical therapy</fact8>, which is consistent with treatment for acute heart failure. 

Given the patient's presentation and lab values, the best explanation for this patient's current presentation is <fact3>type II diabetes</fact3> with possible acute heart failure. However, there is no clear indication of renal tubular acidosis in the lab values provided. The patient's serum bicarbonate level is slightly elevated at <fact12>31 mEq/L</fact12>, which is not indicative of renal tubular acidosis type I or II. The patient's serum calcium level is slightly elevated at <fact16>10.9 mg/dL</fact16>, but there is no clear indication of renal tubular acidosis type IV. Therefore, the best explanation for this patient's current presentation is not clearly related to renal tubular acidosis.

However, the patient's presentation and lab values are most consistent with the effects of <fact4>lisinopril</fact4> and <fact8>BIPAP and medical therapy</fact8> for acute heart failure. The patient's symptoms improved rapidly with this treatment, and the lab values show no clear indication of renal tubular acidosis.

question:
A 45-year-old female presents to the emergency department with gross hematuria and acute, colicky flank pain. She denies any previous episodes of hematuria. She reports taking high doses of acetaminophen and aspirin over several weeks due to persistent upper back pain. The patient’s blood pressure and temperature are normal, but she is found to have proteinuria. Physical examination is negative for palpable flank masses. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis:
A) Diffuse cortical necrosis
B) Chronic pyelonephritis
C) Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
D) Papillary necrosis
E) Acute Nephrolithiasis
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>45-year-old female</fact1> presents to the emergency department with <fact2>gross hematuria</fact2> and <fact3>acute, colicky flank pain</fact3>. She denies any previous episodes of <fact2>hematuria</fact2>. She reports taking high doses of <fact4>acetaminophen</fact4> and <fact5>aspirin</fact5> over several weeks due to <fact6>persistent upper back pain</fact6>. The patient’s <fact7>blood pressure</fact7> and <fact8>temperature</fact8> are normal, but she is found to have <fact9>proteinuria</fact9>. Physical examination is <fact10>negative for palpable flank masses</fact10>. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Answer: Considering the patient's presentation of <fact2>gross hematuria</fact2> and <fact3>acute, colicky flank pain</fact3>, it is essential to evaluate for potential causes of these symptoms. The patient's history of taking high doses of <fact4>acetaminophen</fact4> and <fact5>aspirin</fact5> over several weeks due to <fact6>persistent upper back pain</fact6> is a significant factor. Acetaminophen and aspirin are both known to cause renal damage, particularly in individuals who take high doses for extended periods. The presence of <fact9>proteinuria</fact9> further supports renal involvement. The absence of <fact10>palpable flank masses</fact10> on physical examination makes conditions such as kidney stones or a kidney mass less likely. Among the provided options, <fact11>papillary necrosis</fact11> is a condition that can be caused by long-term use of analgesics, leading to renal damage and symptoms such as <fact2>gross hematuria</fact2> and <fact3>acute, colicky flank pain</fact3>. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is {D}.

question:
A 65-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of repeated falls, postural dizziness, progressive fatigue, generalized weakness and a 13.6 kg (30 lb) weight loss. He is a vegetarian. The patient’s family says that he had been high functioning but has had significant behavioral changes over the past year. The patient denies any smoking history, alcohol consumption, or illicit drug use. No significant family history. His vital signs include: blood pressure 90/50 mm Hg without postural changes, pulse 92/min, respiratory rate 16/min, temperature 37.0℃ (98.6℉). Physical examination reveals a poorly groomed, disheveled, thin man. He is irritable, paranoid, and delusional but denies any hallucinations. An unstable, wide-based ataxic gait is noted. Laboratory results are significant for the following:
Hb 6.1 g/dL
MCV 109 fL
Platelets 90,0000/mm3
Total count 3,000/mm3
Reticulocyte count 0.8%
A peripheral blood smear demonstrates hypersegmented neutrophils. Anti-intrinsic factor antibodies are negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
 
A) Hypothyroidism
B) Folate deficiency
C) Vitamin B12 deficiency
D) Parvovirus infection
E) Pernicious anemia
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>65-year-old man</fact1> presents with a <fact2>6-month history of repeated falls</fact2>, <fact3>postural dizziness</fact3>, <fact4>progressive fatigue</fact4>, <fact5>generalized weakness</fact5>, and a <fact6>13.6 kg (30 lb) weight loss</fact6>. He is a <fact7>vegetarian</fact7>. The patient’s family says that he had been <fact8>high functioning</fact8> but has had <fact9>significant behavioral changes</fact9> over the past year. The patient denies any <fact10>smoking history</fact10>, <fact11>alcohol consumption</fact11>, or <fact12>illicit drug use</fact12>. No significant <fact13>family history</fact13>. His vital signs include: <fact14>blood pressure 90/50 mm Hg without postural changes</fact14>, <fact15>pulse 92/min</fact15>, <fact16>respiratory rate 16/min</fact16>, and <fact17>temperature 37.0℃ (98.6℉)</fact17>. Physical examination reveals a <fact18>poorly groomed, disheveled, thin man</fact18>. He is <fact19>irritable, paranoid, and delusional</fact19> but denies any <fact20>hallucinations</fact20>. An <fact21>unstable, wide-based ataxic gait</fact21> is noted. Laboratory results are significant for the following: <fact22>Hb 6.1 g/dL</fact22>, <fact23>MCV 109 fL</fact23>, <fact24>Platelets 90,0000/mm3</fact24>, <fact25>Total count 3,000/mm3</fact25>, <fact26>Reticulocyte count 0.8%</fact26>. A <fact27>peripheral blood smear demonstrates hypersegmented neutrophils</fact27>. <fact28>Anti-intrinsic factor antibodies are negative</fact28>. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

Answer: The patient's presentation, including <fact2>repeated falls</fact2>, <fact3>postural dizziness</fact3>, <fact4>progressive fatigue</fact4>, <fact5>generalized weakness</fact5>, and <fact6>weight loss</fact6>, along with <fact27>hypersegmented neutrophils</fact27> on the <fact27>peripheral blood smear</fact27>, suggests a megaloblastic anemia. The patient's <fact7>vegetarian diet</fact7> increases the likelihood of a vitamin B12 deficiency, as vitamin B12 is primarily found in animal products. However, the presence of <fact28>negative anti-intrinsic factor antibodies</fact28> makes pernicious anemia, an autoimmune disorder that causes a vitamin B12 deficiency due to the destruction of intrinsic factor, less likely. The patient's <fact9>significant behavioral changes</fact9> and <fact21>unstable, wide-based ataxic gait</fact21> also suggest a vitamin B12 deficiency, as this vitamin is essential for the synthesis of myelin and the maintenance of the nervous system. Therefore, the most likely cause of this patient’s condition is a vitamin B12 deficiency.

question:
A 3-year-old refugee with increasing pitting edema and abdominal swelling over the past 2 months is brought to the physician. Her family has been displaced several times over the last few years. Nutrition and housing were frequently inadequate. At the physician’s clinic, the boy appears irritated and drowsy. He is difficult to arouse. Physical examination shows pitting edema over the ankles and feet and around his eyes. Abdominal examination is positive for ascites and hepatomegaly. Oral examination shows several missing teeth. Which of the following best explains these findings?
A) Kwashiorkor
B) Marasmus
C) Beriberi
D) Rickets
E) Scurvy
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>3-year-old refugee</fact1> with <fact2>with increasing pitting edema and abdominal swelling over the past 2 months</fact2> is brought to the physician. Her family has been displaced several times over the last few years. Nutrition and housing were frequently <fact3>inadequate</fact3>. At the physician’s clinic, the boy appears <fact4>irritated and drowsy</fact4>. He is difficult to arouse. Physical examination shows <fact5>pitting edema over the ankles and feet</fact5> and <fact6>around his eyes</fact6>. Abdominal examination is positive for <fact7>ascites and hepatomegaly</fact7>. Oral examination shows <fact8>several missing teeth</fact8>. Which of the following best explains these findings?

Answer: The <fact1>3-year-old refugee</fact1> presents with <fact2>increasing pitting edema and abdominal swelling over the past 2 months</fact2>, indicating malnutrition. The <fact3>inadequate nutrition and housing</fact3> due to frequent displacement are contributing factors. The boy's <fact4>irritability and drowsiness</fact4> suggest severe malnutrition. The presence of <fact5>pitting edema over the ankles and feet</fact5> and <fact6>around his eyes</fact6> is a hallmark of edema, which is a common symptom of malnutrition. The <fact7>ascites and hepatomegaly</fact7> on abdominal examination indicate liver enlargement, which is a result of malnutrition. The <fact8>missing teeth</fact8> on oral examination further support the diagnosis of malnutrition. Among the options, <fact9>Kwashiorkor</fact9> is characterized by edema, liver enlargement, and poor appetite, which matches the boy's presentation. Therefore, the correct answer is {A}.

question:
A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 7-day history of progressively worsening shortness of breath. She has a history of asthma and has frequent exacerbations despite receiving maximal medical therapy. Physical examination shows scattered expiratory wheezing. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 9,800/mm3 (13% eosinophils) and elevated serum concentration of immunoglobulin E. An x-ray of the chest shows thickened bronchial walls and perihilar opacities. Sputum culture shows scattered septate hyphae that branch at 45 degrees. Which of the following is most likely to be increased in this patient?
A) IL-28
B) C5a
C) TGF-β
D) IFN-α
E) IL-4
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>48-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of a <fact2>7-day history of progressively worsening shortness of breath</fact2>. She has a <fact3>history of asthma</fact3> and has <fact4>frequency of exacerbations despite receiving maximal medical therapy</fact4>. Physical examination shows <fact5>scattered expiratory wheezing</fact5>. Laboratory studies show a <fact6>leukocyte count of 9,800/mm3 (13% eosinophils)</fact6> and <fact7>elevated serum concentration of immunoglobulin E</fact7>. An <fact8>x-ray of the chest shows thickened bronchial walls and perihilar opacities</fact8>. <fact9>Sputum culture shows scattered septate hyphae that branch at 45 degrees</fact9>. Which of the following is most likely to be increased in this patient?

Answer: 
The patient has a <fact1>7-day history of progressively worsening shortness of breath</fact1> with a <fact3>history of asthma</fact3> and <fact4>frequency of exacerbations despite receiving maximal medical therapy</fact4>. Her laboratory studies show a <fact6>leukocyte count of 9,800/mm3 (13% eosinophils)</fact6> and <fact7>elevated serum concentration of immunoglobulin E</fact7>, which are indicative of an allergic response. The <fact9>sputum culture shows scattered septate hyphae that branch at 45 degrees</fact9>, which is characteristic of a fungal infection. Given the patient's symptoms and laboratory results, the most likely diagnosis is allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), a condition associated with an overactive immune response to Aspergillus fumigatus. In ABPA, <fact8>IL-4</fact8> is often increased due to the Th2 cell response, which is responsible for the allergic inflammation. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her father because of fever, chills, abdominal pain, and profuse non-bloody diarrhea. Her symptoms began one week ago, when she had several days of low-grade fever and constipation. She returned from Indonesia 2 weeks ago, where she spent the summer with her grandparents. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.8°F). Examination shows diffuse abdominal tenderness and mild hepatosplenomegaly. There is a faint salmon-colored maculopapular rash on her trunk and abdomen. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
A) Giardia lamblia
B) Schistosoma mansoni
C) Campylobacter jejuni
D) Salmonella typhi
E) Clostridium perfringens
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>14-year-old girl</fact1> is brought to the physician by her father because of <fact2>fever, chills, abdominal pain, and profuse non-bloody diarrhea</fact2>. Her symptoms began <fact3>one week ago</fact3>, when she had several days of <fact4>low-grade fever and constipation</fact4>. She returned from <fact5>Indonesia</fact5> <fact6>2 weeks ago</fact6>, where she spent the summer with her grandparents. Her <fact7>temperature is 39.3°C (102.8°F)</fact7>. Examination shows <fact8>diffuse abdominal tenderness and mild hepatosplenomegaly</fact8>. There is a <fact9>faint salmon-colored maculopapular rash</fact9> on her <fact10>trunk and abdomen</fact10>. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?

A) Giardia lamblia
B) Schistosoma mansoni
C) Campylobacter jejuni
D) Salmonella typhi
E) Clostridium perfringens

Answer: The patient's symptoms of <fact2>fever, chills, abdominal pain, and profuse non-bloody diarrhea</fact2> that began <fact3>one week ago</fact3> suggest a gastrointestinal infection. The presence of a <fact9>faint salmon-colored maculopapular rash</fact9> on her <fact10>trunk and abdomen</fact10> is a key finding, as it is often associated with typhoid fever caused by <fact11>Salmonella typhi</fact11>. The patient's recent travel to <fact5>Indonesia</fact5> further supports this diagnosis, as <fact11>Salmonella typhi</fact11> is a common cause of typhoid fever in Southeast Asia. Therefore, the most likely causal organism is {D}.

question:
A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider concerned that she may be pregnant. She has a history of regular menstruation every 4 weeks that lasts about 4 days with mild to moderate bleeding, but she missed her last period 2 weeks ago. A home pregnancy test was positive. She has a 6-year history of hyperthyroidism that is well-controlled with daily methimazole. She is currently asymptomatic and has no complaints or concerns. A blood specimen is taken and confirms the diagnosis. Additionally, her thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is 2.0 μU/mL. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
A) Continue methimazole
B) Discontinue methimazole, start propylthiouracil
C) Add glucocorticoids
D) Add propranolol
E) Refer for radioiodine therapy
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>35-year-old woman</fact1> presents to her primary care provider concerned that she may be pregnant. She has a history of regular menstruation every 4 weeks that lasts about 4 days with <fact2>mild to moderate bleeding</fact2>, but she missed her last period 2 weeks ago. A <fact3>home pregnancy test</fact3> was positive. She has a 6-year history of <fact4>hyperthyroidism</fact4> that is well-controlled with daily <fact5>methimazole</fact5>. She is currently <fact6>asymptomatic</fact6> and has no complaints or concerns. A <fact7>blood specimen</fact7> is taken and confirms the diagnosis. Additionally, her <fact8>thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)</fact8> is <fact9>2.0 μU/mL</fact9>. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

Answer: The patient is a <fact1>35-year-old woman</fact1> who is confirmed to be pregnant and has a history of <fact4>hyperthyroidism</fact4> that is well-controlled with daily <fact5>methimazole</fact5>. Methimazole is a thionamide medication that is used to treat hyperthyroidism, but it is contraindicated in pregnancy due to the risk of <fact10>congenital anomalies</fact10> and <fact11>neonatal hypothyroidism</fact11>. The next best step in the management of this patient is to discontinue methimazole and start propylthiouracil, which is another thionamide medication that is safer to use during pregnancy. Therefore, the correct answer is {B}.

question:
A 55-year-old man recovering from knee replacement surgery complains of breathlessness in the postoperative ward. He has been confined to bed for the past 5 days and is under observation. He felt a sudden difficulty in breathing and called for the ward nurse. He says that he is unable to take deep breaths and has a sharp pain on the right side of his chest with each inspiration. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.8°F), the pulse is 111/min, the respirations are 31/min, and the blood pressure is 85/55 mm Hg. He experiences pain in his right calf on dorsiflexion. There are no other prominent findings on physical examination. His chest X-ray does not show anything significant. The ECG reveals sinus tachycardia. Which of the following is the best course of management at this time?
A) Subcutaneous fondaparinux
B) CT scan
C) Inferior vena cava filter
D) Ventilation-perfusion scan
E) Lower extremity doppler
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>55-year-old man</fact1> recovering from <fact2>knee replacement surgery</fact2> complains of <fact3>breathlessness</fact3> in the postoperative ward. He has been confined to bed for the past <fact4>5 days</fact4> and is under observation. He felt a sudden difficulty in breathing and called for the ward nurse. He says that he is unable to take deep breaths and has a sharp pain on the <fact5>right side of his chest</fact5> with each inspiration. His <fact6>temperature is 37.5°C (99.8°F)</fact6>, the <fact7>pulse is 111/min</fact7>, the <fact8>respirations are 31/min</fact8>, and the <fact9>blood pressure is 85/55 mm Hg</fact9>. He experiences pain in his <fact10>right calf on dorsiflexion</fact10>. There are no other prominent findings on physical examination. His <fact11>chest X-ray does not show anything significant</fact11>. The <fact12>ECG reveals sinus tachycardia</fact12>. Which of the following is the best course of management at this time?

Answer: The patient is a <fact1>55-year-old man</fact1> recovering from <fact2>knee replacement surgery</fact2> and presents with <fact3>breathlessness</fact3> and <fact5>sharp pain on the right side of his chest</fact5> with each inspiration. These symptoms, combined with his <fact7>pulse of 111/min</fact7> and <fact8>respirations of 31/min</fact8>, suggest a possible pulmonary embolism (PE). The <fact10>pain in his right calf on dorsiflexion</fact10> is a positive Homan's sign, which is indicative of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), a common cause of PE. The <fact12>ECG revealing sinus tachycardia</fact12> is consistent with a stress response to the embolism. Given these findings, the best course of management is to administer anticoagulation therapy to prevent further clot formation and reduce the risk of another embolism. Among the options provided, <fact13>subcutaneous fondaparinux</fact13> is a low molecular weight heparin that is commonly used for the treatment and prevention of DVT and PE. Therefore, the best course of management at this time is {A}.

question:
A 56-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of increasing confusion, generalized fatigue, and irritability for the past week. She has been unable to recall her husband's name or their address. She has had insomnia and daytime sleepiness during this period. Her last bowel movement was 3 days ago. One month ago, she underwent a transjugular intrahepatic portal shunt (TIPS) placement. She has alcoholic liver cirrhosis. Current medications include spironolactone and furosemide. She used to drink over a pint of vodka daily but quit 2 months ago. She is oriented to place and person. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 102/64 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus and jaundice. There are several telangiectasias over the chest and back. Palmar erythema is present. The abdomen is mildly distended and nontender. Shifting dullness is present. There is a flapping tremor of both hands when outstretched and dorsiflexed. Neurologic examination shows no other focal findings. She completes the number connection test slower than the age-normalized standard. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Reversal of TIPS
B) Paracentesis
C) Administer IV ceftriaxone
D) Administer lactulose
E) Administer vitamin B1
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>56-year-old woman</fact1> is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of <fact2>increasing confusion, generalized fatigue, and irritability</fact2> for the past week. She has been unable to recall her husband's name or their address. She has had <fact3>insomnia and daytime sleepiness</fact3> during this period. Her last bowel movement was <fact4>3 days ago</fact4>. One month ago, she underwent a <fact5>transjugular intrahepatic portal shunt (TIPS) placement</fact5>. She has <fact6>alcoholic liver cirrhosis</fact6>. Current medications include <fact7>spironolactone and furosemide</fact7>. She used to drink over a pint of vodka daily but quit <fact8>2 months ago</fact8>. She is oriented to <fact9>place and person</fact9>. Her <fact10>temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F)</fact10>, <fact11>pulse is 88/min</fact11>, and <fact12>blood pressure is 102/64 mm Hg</fact12>. Examination shows <fact13>scleral icterus and jaundice</fact13>. There are several <fact14>telangiectasias over the chest and back</fact14>. <fact15>Palmar erythema is present</fact15>. The <fact16>abdomen is mildly distended and nontender</fact16>. <fact17>Shifting dullness is present</fact17>. There is a <fact18>flapping tremor of both hands when outstretched and dorsiflexed</fact18>. Neurologic examination shows no other <fact19>focal findings</fact19>. She completes the <fact20>number connection test slower than the age-normalized standard</fact20>. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: 
The patient has a history of <fact6>alcoholic liver cirrhosis</fact6> and underwent a <fact5>transjugular intrahepatic portal shunt (TIPS) placement</fact5> one month ago. She is experiencing <fact2>increasing confusion, generalized fatigue, and irritability</fact2> for the past week, which could be indicative of hepatic encephalopathy. The presence of <fact13>scleral icterus and jaundice</fact13>, <fact14>telangiectasias over the chest and back</fact14>, <fact15>palmar erythema</fact15>, and <fact16>shifting dullness</fact16> are all consistent with cirrhosis. The <fact18>flapping tremor of both hands when outstretched and dorsiflexed</fact18> is a classic sign of hepatic encephalopathy. Given these findings, the most appropriate next step in management is to administer lactulose to reduce ammonia levels in the blood and alleviate hepatic encephalopathy symptoms. Therefore, the correct answer is {D}.

question:
A 62-year-old man presents with bright red blood in his stool which occurred 2 times this week. He denies fever, weight loss, pain, pruritus or urinary symptoms. Past medical history is significant for gastroesophageal reflux disease, and recent appendicitis, status post laparoscopic appendectomy complicated by delirium tremens. His vitals are a temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure of 130/80 mm Hg, pulse of 78/min, and respiratory rate of 12/min. Physical examination reveals a distended abdomen with shifting dullness on percussion. In addition, multiple purple spider web-like lesions are present on the chest and arms, which blanch when pressure is applied. Fecal occult blood test is negative. On anoscopy, a non-tender, dilated vascular protrusion is noted superior to the pectinate line. Which of the following is most likely true about this patient’s current symptoms?
A) This patient has peptic ulcer disease.
B) The vascular protrusion drains into the superior rectal vein.
C) The vascular protrusion drains into the inferior vena cava.
D) The vascular protrusion drains into the inferior rectal vein.
E) Fecal leukocytes and a stool culture are required for diagnosis.
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>62-year-old man</fact1> presents with <fact2>bright red blood in his stool</fact2> which occurred <fact3>2 times this week</fact3>. He denies <fact4>fever</fact4>, <fact5>weight loss</fact5>, <fact6>pain</fact6>, <fact7>pruritus</fact7> or <fact8>urinary symptoms</fact8>. Past medical history is significant for <fact9>gastroesophageal reflux disease</fact9>, and recent <fact10>appendicitis</fact10>, status post <fact11>laparoscopic appendectomy</fact11> complicated by <fact12>delirium tremens</fact12>. His vitals are a <fact13>temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F)</fact13>, <fact14>blood pressure of 130/80 mm Hg</fact14>, <fact15>pulse of 78/min</fact15>, and <fact16>respiratory rate of 12/min</fact16>. Physical examination reveals a <fact17>distended abdomen with shifting dullness on percussion</fact17>. In addition, multiple <fact18>purple spider web-like lesions</fact18> are present on the chest and arms, which <fact19>blanch when pressure is applied</fact19>. <fact20>Fecal occult blood test is negative</fact20>. On <fact21>anoscopy</fact21>, a <fact22>non-tender, dilated vascular protrusion</fact22> is noted <fact23>superior to the pectinate line</fact23>. Which of the following is most likely true about this patient’s current symptoms?

Answer: The patient's symptoms of <fact2>bright red blood in his stool</fact2> and the presence of <fact22>non-tender, dilated vascular protrusion</fact22> on <fact21>anoscopy</fact21> are indicative of a hemorrhoid. The <fact22>non-tender, dilated vascular protrusion</fact22> is likely a prolapsed hemorrhoid, which is a common cause of bright red blood in the stool. The fact that the <fact22>non-tender, dilated vascular protrusion</fact22> is located <fact23>superior to the pectinate line</fact23> further supports this diagnosis, as hemorrhoids that occur above the pectinate line are more likely to be internal hemorrhoids. The <fact18>purple spider web-like lesions</fact18> on the chest and arms, which <fact19>blanch when pressure is applied</fact19>, are also consistent with hemorrhoids, as they are a common sign of this condition. Therefore, the most likely true statement about this patient’s current symptoms is that the <fact22>non-tender, dilated vascular protrusion</fact22> drains into the <fact24>superior rectal vein</fact24>.

question:
A 75-year-old man presents to the physician for his annual blood pressure visit and blood work. He has no complaints other than occasional knee pain. The past medical history includes hypertension. He has had knee osteoarthritis for several years and takes occasional acetaminophen for pain control. His diet is full of vegetables. He exercises every day. He has no history of smoking. He had a brother who died at the age of 84 due to hematologic malignancy. The temperature is 36.8℃ (98.2℉), and the blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. The physical examination shows no abnormalities other than a reduced range of motion and crepitus in both knees. The laboratory test results are as follows:
Hemoglobin 15 g/dL
Leukocyte count 58,000/mm3
Platelet count 250,000/mm3
Flow cytometry on the peripheral blood reveals an absolute lymphocyte count of 50,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)
B) Monoclonal B cell lymphocytosis (MBL)
C) Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS)
D) Multiple myeloma (MM)
E) Polycythemia vera (PV)
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>75-year-old man</fact1> presents to the physician for his annual blood pressure visit and blood work. He has no complaints other than occasional <fact2>knee pain</fact2>. The past medical history includes <fact3>hypertension</fact3>. He has had <fact4>knee osteoarthritis</fact4> for several years and takes occasional <fact5>acetaminophen for pain control</fact5>. His diet is full of <fact6>vegetables</fact6>. He exercises every day. He has no history of <fact7>smoking</fact7>. He had a <fact8>brother who died at the age of 84 due to hematologic malignancy</fact8>. The <fact9>temperature is 36.8℃ (98.2℉)</fact9>, and the <fact10>blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg</fact10>. The physical examination shows no abnormalities other than a <fact11>reduced range of motion</fact11> and <fact12>crepitus in both knees</fact12>. The laboratory test results are as follows:
Hemoglobin <fact13>15 g/dL</fact13>
Leukocyte count <fact14>58,000/mm3</fact14>
Platelet count <fact15>250,000/mm3</fact15>
Flow cytometry on the peripheral blood reveals an absolute <fact16>lymphocyte count of 50,000/mm3</fact16>. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Answer: 
The patient's laboratory test results show an elevated leukocyte count of <fact14>58,000/mm3</fact14> and an absolute lymphocyte count of <fact16>50,000/mm3</fact16>. This is indicative of a lymphoproliferative disorder. The patient's history of <fact8>hematologic malignancy in a first-degree relative</fact8> also increases his risk for developing a hematologic malignancy. Among the options provided, <fact17>Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)</fact17> is the most likely diagnosis. CLL is characterized by an elevated leukocyte count and an absolute lymphocyte count, often in the absence of symptoms. The patient's age and history also support this diagnosis.

question:
A previously healthy 29-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of burning with urination for several days. He has also had pain in the right ankle for 3 days and pain and swelling in the left knee for 1 day. Two weeks ago, he had several days of fever and bloody diarrhea, for which he was treated with antibiotics. Examination shows a small left knee effusion and bilateral conjunctival injection. Which of the following is the most likely additional finding in this patient?
A) Circular erythematous rash with central clearing
B) Pain on passive extension of the fingers
C) Palpable mass in the right lower quadrant
D) Tenderness at the insertion of the Achilles tendon
E) Nontender subcutaneous nodules over the olecranon
answer:
Reformatted Question: A previously healthy <fact1>29-year-old man</fact1> comes to the emergency department because of <fact2>burning with urination</fact2> for several days. He has also had <fact3>pain in the right ankle</fact3> for 3 days and <fact4>pain and swelling in the left knee</fact4> for 1 day. Two weeks ago, he had several days of <fact5>fever and bloody diarrhea</fact5>, for which he was treated with <fact6>antibiotics</fact6>. Examination shows a <fact7>small left knee effusion</fact7> and <fact8>bilateral conjunctival injection</fact8>. Which of the following is the most likely additional finding in this patient?

Answer: Evaluating the patient's presentation, the <fact1>29-year-old man</fact1> is experiencing <fact2>burning with urination</fact2>, <fact3>pain in the right ankle</fact3>, and <fact4>pain and swelling in the left knee</fact4>, which are symptoms suggestive of a systemic infection. The <fact5>fever and bloody diarrhea</fact5> he experienced two weeks ago, for which he was treated with <fact6>antibiotics</fact6>, could be indicative of a gastrointestinal infection. The presence of <fact7>a small left knee effusion</fact7> and <fact8>bilateral conjunctival injection</fact8> suggests a possible rheumatologic or infectious process. Among the options provided, <fact9>pain on passive extension of the fingers</fact9> is a characteristic finding in Reiter's syndrome, a form of reactive arthritis that can occur in response to a gastrointestinal or urinary tract infection. This condition is consistent with the patient's symptoms and medical history. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 32-year-old man comes to the physician for a pre-employment examination. He recently traveled to Guatemala. He feels well but has not seen a physician in several years, and his immunization records are unavailable. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:
Anti-HAV IgM Positive
Anti-HAV IgG Negative
HBsAg Negative
Anti-HBs Positive
HBcAg Negative
Anti-HBc Negative
HBeAg Negative
Anti-HBe Negative
Anti-HCV Negative
Which of the following best explains this patient's laboratory findings?"
A) Active hepatitis B infection
B) Active hepatitis A infection
C) Previous hepatitis A infection
D) Chronic hepatitis B infection
E) Chronic hepatitis C infection
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>32-year-old man</fact1> comes to the physician for a pre-employment examination. He recently traveled to <fact2>Guatemala</fact2>. He feels well but has not seen a physician in several years, and his immunization records are unavailable. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:
<fact3>Anti-HAV IgM Positive</fact3>
<fact4>Anti-HAV IgG Negative</fact4>
<fact5>HBsAg Negative</fact5>
<fact6>Anti-HBs Positive</fact6>
<fact7>HBcAg Negative</fact7>
<fact8>Anti-HBc Negative</fact8>
<fact9>HBeAg Negative</fact9>
<fact10>Anti-HBe Negative</fact10>
<fact11>Anti-HCV Negative</fact11>
Which of the following best explains this patient's laboratory findings?

Answer: The patient's serum studies show the presence of <fact3>Anti-HAV IgM Positive</fact3> and <fact4>Anti-HAV IgG Negative</fact4>. The presence of <fact3>Anti-HAV IgM Positive</fact3> indicates an active <fact2>hepatitis A infection</fact2>, as IgM antibodies are produced in response to a recent infection. The absence of <fact4>Anti-HAV IgG Positive</fact4> suggests that the patient has not previously been infected with hepatitis A virus. Therefore, the correct answer is {B}.

question:
A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. Six months ago, she was vaccinated against influenza. Her last mammography 1 year ago showed no abnormalities. Two years ago, a pap smear and colonoscopy were normal. She has a history of hypertension. Her father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 50 years. She emigrated from Japan 30 years ago. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for the last 18 years. She drinks 4–5 glasses of wine per day. She goes ballroom dancing twice each week. Her medications include enalapril and low-dose aspirin. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 50 kg (110 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a soft S4 gallop. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Pap smear
B) Dual-energy x-ray bone absorptiometry
C) Abdominal ultrasonography
D) Low-dose chest CT
E) Transesophageal echocardiography
answer:

A <fact1>62-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician for a <fact2>routine health maintenance examination</fact2>. She feels <fact3>well</fact3>. Six months ago, she was vaccinated against <fact4>influenza</fact4>. Her last <fact5>mammography</fact5> 1 year ago showed no <fact6>abnormalities</fact6>. She has <fact14>smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for the last 18 years</fact14>. She drinks <fact15>4–5 glasses of wine per day</fact15>. She goes <fact16>ballroom dancing twice each week</fact16>. Her <fact17>medications</fact17> include <fact18>enalapril</fact18> and <fact19>low-dose aspirin</fact19>. She is <fact20>165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall</fact20> and weighs <fact21>50 kg (110 lb)</fact21>; <fact22>BMI is 18 kg/m2</fact22>. <fact23>Vital signs are within normal limits</fact23>. <fact24>Cardiopulmonary examination shows a soft S4 gallop</fact24>. The remainder of the examination shows no <fact25>abnormalities</fact25>. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>62-year-old woman</fact1> is coming in for a <fact2>routine health maintenance examination</fact2>, it's essential to assess her risk factors for various diseases and implement preventive measures accordingly. Given her family history of <fact11>myocardial infarction</fact11> at a relatively young age, her <fact14>smoking history</fact14>, and her <fact15>alcohol consumption</fact15>, she is at increased risk for cardiovascular disease. Her <fact17>medications</fact17> include <fact18>enalapril</fact18> and <fact19>low-dose aspirin</fact19>, which are commonly used to manage hypertension and prevent cardiovascular events. However, given her smoking history, a more aggressive approach to cardiovascular risk reduction may be warranted. Among the options provided, the most appropriate next step in management would be to perform a <fact20>low-dose chest CT</fact20> to screen for lung cancer, which is a common cause of cancer-related mortality, particularly in smokers. Additionally, given her family history of myocardial infarction, a <fact20>low-dose chest CT</fact20> may also provide valuable information about her cardiovascular health. The answer is {D}.

question:
A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of difficulty falling asleep for the past 2 months. She wakes up frequently during the night and gets up earlier than desired. She experiences discomfort in her legs when lying down at night and feels the urge to move her legs. The discomfort resolves when she gets up and walks around or moves her legs. She has tried an over-the-counter sleep aid that contains diphenhydramine, which worsened her symptoms. She exercises regularly and eats a well-balanced diet. She admits that she has been under a lot of stress lately. Her brother has similar symptoms. The patient appears anxious. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and iron studies are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's symptoms?
A) Amitryptiline
B) Pramipexole
C) Codeine
D) Propranolol
E) Escitalopram
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>38-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>difficulty falling asleep</fact2> for the past <fact3>2 months</fact3>. She wakes up frequently during the night and gets up earlier than desired. She experiences <fact4>discomfort in her legs when lying down at night</fact4> and feels the urge to move her legs. The discomfort resolves when she gets up and walks around or moves her legs. She has tried an over-the-counter sleep aid that contains <fact5>diphenhydramine</fact5>, which worsened her symptoms. She exercises regularly and eats a well-balanced diet. She admits that she has been under a lot of <fact6>stress lately</fact6>. Her <fact7>brother has similar symptoms</fact7>. The patient appears <fact8>anxious</fact8>. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and iron studies are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's symptoms?

Answer: Based on the patient's symptoms of <fact2>difficulty falling asleep</fact2>, <fact4>discomfort in her legs when lying down at night</fact4>, and <fact8>anxiety</fact8>, along with a family history of similar symptoms, the most likely diagnosis is restless leg syndrome (RLS). The patient's symptoms are consistent with the diagnostic criteria for RLS, which include an urge to move the legs, usually accompanied by uncomfortable sensations, and symptoms that worsen in the evening or at night and improve with movement. The patient's use of <fact5>diphenhydramine</fact5>, which worsened her symptoms, suggests that she may have been experiencing rebound insomnia. Among the options provided, <fact9>pramipexole</fact9> is a dopamine agonist that is commonly used to treat RLS. It is a dopamine agonist that works by stimulating dopamine receptors in the brain, which helps to reduce the urge to move the legs and alleviate uncomfortable sensations. Therefore, the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's symptoms is <fact10>pramipexole</fact10>.

question:
A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 40 minutes after being involved in a shooting. He sustained a gunshot wound in an altercation outside of a bar. On arrival, he is oriented to person but not to place or time. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 116/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 79/42 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Examination shows multiple abrasions over the arms and thorax. There is a 1-cm (0.4-in) entry wound with minimal bleeding on the right side of the chest in the 6th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Abdominal examination shows diffuse mild tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. A focused assessment with sonography shows no obvious free fluid in the pericardium; assessment of the abdomen is equivocal. An x-ray of the chest shows mild opacification of the right lower lobe. Two large-bore cannulas are inserted and intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun. The patient is intubated and mechanical ventilation is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Chest tube insertion in the fifth intercostal space at the midaxillary line
B) CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis
C) Local wound exploration
D) Exploratory laparotomy
E) Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery
answer:

He sustained a <fact3>gunshot wound</fact3> in an altercation outside of a bar. On arrival, he is <fact4>oriented to person but not to place or time</fact4>. His <fact5>temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F)</fact5>, <fact6>pulse is 116/min</fact6>, <fact7>respirations are 18/min</fact7>, and <fact8>blood pressure is 79/42 mm Hg</fact8>. <fact9>Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%</fact9>. There is a <fact11>1-cm (0.4-in) entry wound with minimal bleeding</fact11> on the <fact12>right side of the chest</fact12> in the <fact13>6th intercostal space at the midclavicular line</fact13>. <fact14>Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities</fact14>. <fact15>Abdominal examination shows diffuse mild tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound</fact15>. A <fact16>focused assessment with sonography shows no obvious free fluid in the pericardium</fact16>; <fact17>assessment of the abdomen is equivocal</fact17>. An <fact18>x-ray of the chest shows mild opacification of the right lower lobe</fact18>. Two <fact19>large-bore cannulas are inserted</fact19> and <fact20>intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun</fact20>. The patient is <fact21>intubated and mechanical ventilation is begun</fact21>. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: Considering the patient's presentation, the <fact1>36-year-old man</fact1> is <fact2>oriented to person but not to place or time</fact2>, indicating altered mental status. His <fact5>temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F)</fact5>, <fact6>pulse is 116/min</fact6>, <fact7>respirations are 18/min</fact7>, and <fact8>blood pressure is 79/42 mm Hg</fact8>, suggesting hemodynamic instability. The presence of a <fact11>1-cm (0.4-in) entry wound with minimal bleeding</fact11> on the <fact12>right side of the chest</fact12> in the <fact13>6th intercostal space at the midclavicular line</fact13> is consistent with a penetrating trauma. Given the patient's altered mental status, hemodynamic instability, and penetrating trauma, the most appropriate next step in management is to perform a <fact22>CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis</fact22> to evaluate for potential injuries to the lungs, liver, spleen, and other organs. This will help guide further management and potential interventions.

question:
A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a change in his personality. The mother reports that over the past 7 months her son has become increasingly withdrawn; he has not answered any phone calls or visited his family and friends. He had always been a quiet boy, who needed some time on his own, but he used to meet with friends at least once a week. The patient says that he cannot leave the house because aliens are watching him and “stealing his thoughts”. He does not drink alcohol. He used to smoke marijuana occasionally but quit 1 year ago. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, it is impossible to follow the patient's sequence of thoughts. He is anxious and has a flat affect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Brief psychotic disorder
B) Delusional disorder
C) Mood disorder with psychotic features
D) Schizoid personality disorder
E) Schizophrenia
answer:

The mother reports that over the past <fact3>7 months</fact3> her son has become increasingly <fact4>withdrawn</fact4>; he has not answered any phone calls or visited his family and friends. He had always been a <fact5>quiet boy</fact5>, who needed some time on his own, but he used to meet with friends at least once a week. The patient says that he cannot leave the house because <fact6>aliens are watching him</fact6> and “<fact7>stealing his thoughts</fact7>”. He does not drink alcohol. He used to smoke <fact8>marijuana occasionally</fact8> but quit <fact9>1 year ago</fact9>. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, it is impossible to follow the patient's <fact10>sequence of thoughts</fact10>. He is <fact11>anxious</fact11> and has a <fact12>flat affect</fact12>. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Answer: Evaluating the patient's presentation, the <fact1>23-year-old man</fact1> is experiencing a <fact2>change in his personality</fact2> over the past <fact3>7 months</fact3>, which is characterized by increasing <fact4>withdrawal</fact4> from social interactions. He reports experiencing <fact6>delusions</fact6> that <fact7>aliens are watching him</fact7> and “<fact7>stealing his thoughts</fact7>”, which is indicative of a psychotic disorder. Additionally, he displays <fact10>disorganized thinking</fact10> and <fact11>anxiety</fact11> with a <fact12>flat affect</fact12> on mental status examination. Considering these factors, the most likely diagnosis is schizophrenia, a chronic and severe mental disorder characterized by <fact2>hallucinations</fact2>, <fact6>delusions</fact6>, and <fact10>disorganized thinking</fact10>. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 29-year-old man diagnosed with schizophrenia 4 years ago presents for follow-up to discuss his medication. The patient was diagnosed with schizophrenia 4 years ago and has since tried several antipsychotic medications, none of which have been able to treat his negative symptoms. He has changed to clozapine 2 weeks ago and says that he does feel better. His physical exam is unremarkable, and he is responding appropriately to questioning. If this patient’s current medication is to be continued, which of the following laboratory tests should be ordered at this time?
 
A) Slit-lamp examination
B) Electrocardiogram
C) Prolactin level
D) Complete blood count
E) Thyroid-stimulating hormone level
answer:
