The patient is a known IV drug abuser but otherwise has an unknown past medical history. He currently attends a methadone clinic. His <fact2>temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C)</fact2>, <fact3>blood pressure is 97/48 mmHg</fact3>, <fact4>pulse is 140/min</fact4>, <fact5>respirations are 29/min</fact5>, and <fact6>oxygen saturation is 98% on room air</fact6>. Initial laboratory values are shown below.

Serum:
Na+: 139 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
K+: 6.3 mEq/L
HCO3-: 17 mEq/L
Glucose: 589 mg/dL

The patient is given treatment. After treatment, his <fact7>temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C)</fact7>, <fact8>blood pressure is 117/78 mmHg</fact8>, <fact9>pulse is 100/min</fact9>, <fact10>respirations are 23/min</fact10>, and <fact11>oxygen saturation is 98% on room air</fact11>. His laboratory values are seen below.

Serum:
Na+: 139 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
K+: 4.3 mEq/L
HCO3-: 19 mEq/L
Glucose: 90 mg/dL

Which of the following is the best next step in management?

Answer: The patient initially presented with <fact2>hyperglycemia</fact2> with a <fact12>glucose level of 589 mg/dL</fact12> and <fact13>hyperkalemia</fact13> with a <fact14>K+ level of 6.3 mEq/L</fact14>. The treatment administered likely included insulin and possibly potassium replacement, as evidenced by the post-treatment <fact15>glucose level of 90 mg/dL</fact15> and <fact16>K+ level of 4.3 mEq/L</fact16>. The patient's <fact17>temperature, blood pressure, pulse, respirations, and oxygen saturation</fact17> are now stable, indicating that the treatment was effective. The best next step in management would be to continue supportive therapy and close monitoring to ensure the patient's condition does not deteriorate. Therefore, the correct answer is {E}.

question:
A 36-year-old man presents to his physician for a regular checkup, and he expresses an intent to quit smoking. He is a financial director with a 15-pack-year history of smoking who tried quitting several times. He tried different nicotine replacement products, none of which helped him. The patient has gastrointestinal reflux disease and takes omeprazole. The medical history is significant for a head trauma after which he had two seizure episodes. He does not have a history of any other disorders. Currently, he is not on any antiepileptic medication. He heard from his friend about an antidepressant that efficiently helps with smoking cessation. He would like to try this medication, and asks his physician for an advice. Which of the following statements regarding the use of the mentioned medication is correct?
A) Omeprazole interferes with bupropion metabolism and should be taken one hour prior to omeprazole consumption.
B) Bupropion is only effective when used together with nicotine replacement products.
C) Bupropion lowers the seizure threshold and it should not be taken by patients with a history of seizure disorder.
D) The physician may prescribe bupropion for this patient only after a full cardiac workup is performed.
E) This patient has no contraindications for bupropion and may safely use it.
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>36-year-old man</fact1> presents to his physician for a regular checkup, and he expresses an intent to quit smoking. He is a financial director with a <fact2>15-pack-year history of smoking</fact2> who tried quitting several times. He tried different <fact3>nicotine replacement products</fact3>, none of which helped him. The patient has <fact4>gastrointestinal reflux disease</fact4> and takes <fact5>omeprazole</fact5>. The medical history is significant for a <fact6>head trauma</fact6> after which he had two <fact7>seizure episodes</fact7>. He does not have a history of any other disorders. Currently, he is not on any <fact8>antiepileptic medication</fact8>. He heard from his friend about an <fact9>antidepressant</fact9> that efficiently helps with <fact10>smoking cessation</fact10>. He would like to try this medication, and asks his physician for an advice. Which of the following statements regarding the use of the mentioned medication is correct? Options: (A) <fact11>Omeprazole interferes with bupropion metabolism and should be taken one hour prior to omeprazole consumption</fact11>. (B) <fact12>Bupropion is only effective when used together with nicotine replacement products</fact12>. (C) <fact13>Bupropion lowers the seizure threshold and it should not be taken by patients with a history of seizure disorder</fact13>. (D) <fact14>The physician may prescribe bupropion for this patient only after a full cardiac workup is performed</fact14>. (E) <fact15>This patient has no contraindications for bupropion and may safely use it</fact15>.

Answer: The patient is a <fact1>36-year-old man</fact1> with a <fact2>15-pack-year history of smoking</fact2> who wants to quit smoking. He has tried different <fact3>nicotine replacement products</fact3> but had no success. He also has <fact4>gastrointestinal reflux disease</fact4> and takes <fact5>omeprazole</fact5>. His medical history includes a <fact6>head trauma</fact6> after which he had two <fact7>seizure episodes</fact7>. He is not on any <fact8>antiepileptic medication</fact8> currently. He is interested in using an <fact9>antidepressant</fact9> that efficiently helps with <fact10>smoking cessation</fact10>. The most likely antidepressant he is referring to is <fact11>bupropion</fact11>, which is commonly used for smoking cessation. 

Regarding the use of <fact11>bupropion</fact11>, option (C) <fact13>Bupropion lowers the seizure threshold and it should not be taken by patients with a history of seizure disorder</fact13> is correct. This is because <fact12>bupropion</fact12> can lower the seizure threshold and is contraindicated in patients with a history of seizure disorder, such as the patient in this case.

question:
Candida is injected into the skin of a 38-year-old female patient. Forty-eight hours later, there is a 14 mm raised, slightly hardened area at the injection site. What type of hypersensitivity reaction has occurred and what cell type plays a role?
A) Type I hypersensitivty; eosinophils
B) Type IV hypersensitivity; mast cells
C) Type III hypersensitivity; CD4+ T cells
D) Type IV hypersensitivity; CD4+ T cells
E) Type I hypersensitivity; macrophages
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>38-year-old female</fact1> patient has <fact2>Candida</fact2> injected into the <fact3>skin</fact3>. Forty-eight hours later, there is a <fact4>14 mm raised, slightly hardened area</fact4> at the <fact5>injection site</fact5>. What <fact6>type of hypersensitivity reaction</fact6> has occurred and what <fact7>cell type</fact7> plays a role?

Answer: The <fact1>38-year-old female</fact1> patient's reaction to the <fact2>Candida</fact2> injection is characterized by a <fact4>14 mm raised, slightly hardened area</fact4> at the <fact5>injection site</fact5>, which is indicative of a delayed hypersensitivity reaction. This type of reaction is typically mediated by <fact7>CD4+ T cells</fact7> and is classified as a <fact6>type IV hypersensitivity reaction</fact6>. Therefore, the correct answer is {D}.

question:
A 25-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain. She states that she was walking up the stairs at work when she felt sudden and severe abdominal pain followed by nausea and vomiting. Her past medical history is non-contributory and she is not currently taking any medications. Her temperature is 99.7°F (37.6°C), blood pressure is 122/78 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for an absence of abdominal tenderness, a left adnexal mass, and left adnexal tenderness. A transvaginal ultrasound demonstrates free fluid surrounding the ovary with edema and the presence of doppler flow. A urinary pregnancy test is negative. The patient's symptoms persisted after ibuprofen and acetaminophen. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
A) CT scan of the abdomen
B) Laparoscopy
C) Laparotomy
D) MRI of the pelvis
E) Observation and serial abdominal exams
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>25-year-old woman</fact1> presents to the emergency department with <fact2>abdominal pain</fact2>. She states that she was walking up the stairs at work when she felt sudden and severe <fact3>abdominal pain</fact3> followed by <fact4>nausea and vomiting</fact4>. Her <fact5>past medical history</fact5> is non-contributory and she is not currently taking any <fact6>medications</fact6>. Her <fact7>temperature is 99.7°F (37.6°C)</fact7>, <fact8>blood pressure is 122/78 mmHg</fact8>, <fact9>pulse is 120/min</fact9>, <fact10>respirations are 17/min</fact10>, and <fact11>oxygen saturation is 98% on room air</fact11>. Physical exam is notable for an absence of <fact12>abdominal tenderness</fact12>, a <fact13>left adnexal mass</fact13>, and <fact14>left adnexal tenderness</fact14>. A <fact15>transvaginal ultrasound</fact15> demonstrates <fact16>free fluid surrounding the ovary</fact16> with <fact17>edema</fact17> and the presence of <fact18>doppler flow</fact18>. A <fact19>urinary pregnancy test</fact19> is negative. The patient's symptoms persisted after <fact20>ibuprofen and acetaminophen</fact20>. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

Answer: Based on the patient's presentation of sudden and severe <fact3>abdominal pain</fact3> followed by <fact4>nausea and vomiting</fact4>, and the presence of <fact16>free fluid surrounding the ovary</fact16> with <fact17>edema</fact17> and <fact18>doppler flow</fact18> on the <fact15>transvaginal ultrasound</fact15>, it is likely that the patient is experiencing an ovarian torsion, a medical emergency that requires prompt intervention to prevent permanent damage to the ovary. The absence of <fact12>abdominal tenderness</fact12> and the presence of <fact14>left adnexal tenderness</fact14> further support this diagnosis. Given the patient's symptoms persisted after <fact20>ibuprofen and acetaminophen</fact20>, the best next step in management is to proceed with a surgical intervention to relieve the torsion and restore blood flow to the ovary. Therefore, the best next step in management is {C} Laparotomy.

question:
A 59-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of excruciating left knee pain for 4 days. He underwent a total knee arthroplasty of his left knee joint 4 months ago. He has hypertension and osteoarthritis. Current medications include glucosamine, amlodipine, and meloxicam. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 118/71 mm Hg. Examination shows a tender, swollen left knee joint; range of motion is limited by pain. Analysis of the synovial fluid confirms septic arthritis, and the prosthesis is removed. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
A) Staphylococcus epidermidis
B) Escherichia coli
C) Staphylococcus aureus
D) Pseudomonas aeruginosa
E) Group B Streptococcus
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>59-year-old man</fact1> comes to the emergency department because of <fact2>excruciating left knee pain</fact2> for <fact3>4 days</fact3>. He underwent a <fact4>total knee arthroplasty</fact4> of his <fact5>left knee joint</fact5> <fact6>4 months ago</fact6>. He has <fact7>hypertension</fact7> and <fact8>osteoarthritis</fact8>. Current medications include <fact9>glucosamine</fact9>, <fact10>amlodipine</fact10>, and <fact11>meloxicam</fact11>. His <fact12>temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F)</fact12>, <fact13>pulse is 97/min</fact13>, and <fact14>blood pressure is 118/71 mm Hg</fact14>. Examination shows a <fact15>tender</fact15>, <fact16>swollen left knee joint</fact16>; <fact17>range of motion is limited by pain</fact17>. Analysis of the <fact18>synovial fluid</fact18> confirms <fact19>septic arthritis</fact19>, and the <fact20>prosthesis is removed</fact20>. Which of the following is the most likely <fact21>causal organism</fact21>?

Answer: Considering the patient's presentation of <fact2>excruciating left knee pain</fact2> following a <fact4>total knee arthroplasty</fact4> and the confirmation of <fact19>septic arthritis</fact19> through analysis of the <fact18>synovial fluid</fact18>, the most likely <fact21>causal organism</fact21> is a common pathogen responsible for prosthetic joint infections. Among the options provided, <fact22>Staphylococcus aureus</fact22> is a well-documented cause of prosthetic joint infections, including septic arthritis. This organism is commonly found on the skin and can easily colonize prosthetic joints, leading to infection. The patient's <fact7>hypertension</fact7> and <fact8>osteoarthritis</fact8> are not directly related to the development of septic arthritis, but they do indicate a history of chronic conditions that may have contributed to the patient's overall health status. The patient's current medications, including <fact9>glucosamine</fact9>, <fact10>amlodipine</fact10>, and <fact11>meloxicam</fact11>, are not directly related to the development of septic arthritis, but they do indicate a history of chronic pain management. The patient's <fact12>temperature of 38.1°C (100.6°F)</fact12>, <fact13>pulse of 97/min</fact13>, and <fact14>blood pressure of 118/71 mm Hg</fact14> are indicative of an infectious process, but they do not provide specific information about the causal organism. The patient's <fact15>tender</fact15>, <fact16>swollen left knee joint</fact16> and <fact17>limited range of motion</fact17> are indicative of septic arthritis, but they do not provide specific information about the causal organism. The patient's <fact20>prosthesis removal</fact20> is a treatment for septic arthritis, but it does not provide specific information about the causal organism.

question:
A 79-year-old man presents to the office due to shortness of breath with moderate exertion and a slightly productive cough. He has a medical history of 25 years of heavy smoking. His vitals include: heart rate 89/min, respiratory rate 27/min, and blood pressure 120/90 mm Hg. The physical exam shows increased resonance to percussion, decreased breath sounds, and crackles at the lung base. Chest radiography shows signs of pulmonary hyperinflation. Spirometry shows a forced expiratory volume in the first second (FEV1) of 48%, a forced vital capacity (FVC) of 85%, and an FEV1/FVC ratio of 56%. According to these results, what is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Asthma
B) Lymphangioleiomyomatosis
C) Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
D) Bronchiectasis
E) Heart failure
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>79-year-old man</fact1> presents to the office due to <fact2>shortness of breath with moderate exertion</fact2> and a <fact3>slightly productive cough</fact3>. He has a medical history of <fact4>25 years of heavy smoking</fact4>. His vitals include: <fact5>heart rate 89/min</fact5>, <fact6>respiratory rate 27/min</fact6>, and <fact7>blood pressure 120/90 mm Hg</fact7>. The physical exam shows <fact8>increased resonance to percussion</fact8>, <fact9>decreased breath sounds</fact9>, and <fact10>crackles at the lung base</fact10>. Chest radiography shows signs of <fact11>pulmonary hyperinflation</fact11>. Spirometry shows a <fact12>forced expiratory volume in the first second (FEV1) of 48%</fact12>, a <fact13>forced vital capacity (FVC) of 85%</fact13>, and an <fact14>FEV1/FVC ratio of 56%</fact14>. According to these results, what is the most likely diagnosis?

Answer: Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>shortness of breath with moderate exertion</fact2> and <fact3>slightly productive cough</fact3>, along with a medical history of <fact4>25 years of heavy smoking</fact4>, this patient is at high risk for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The spirometry results, including a <fact12>FEV1 of 48%</fact12> and a <fact14>FEV1/FVC ratio of 56%</fact14>, are consistent with COPD, as the FEV1 is significantly reduced and the FEV1/FVC ratio is decreased, indicating airway obstruction. The presence of <fact8>increased resonance to percussion</fact8> and <fact9>decreased breath sounds</fact9> on physical exam, along with <fact10>crackles at the lung base</fact10>, further supports this diagnosis. Additionally, the chest radiography showing signs of <fact11>pulmonary hyperinflation</fact11> is consistent with COPD. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is <fact15>Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)</fact15>. The answer is {C}.

question:
A 62-year-old man with a history of chronic bronchitis comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of worsening shortness of breath and cough productive of thick sputum. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years but quit 5 years ago. Physical examination shows an increased anteroposterior chest diameter and coarse crackles in the lower lung fields bilaterally. Treatment with a drug that directly antagonizes the effects of vagal stimulation on the airways is begun. Which of the following drugs was most likely started?
A) Fluticasone
B) Montelukast
C) Albuterol
D) Tiotropium
E) Cromolyn
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>62-year-old man</fact1> with a <fact2>history of chronic bronchitis</fact2> comes to the physician because of a <fact3>1-month history of worsening shortness of breath and cough productive of thick sputum</fact3>. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for <fact4>20 years</fact4> but quit <fact5>5 years ago</fact5>. Physical examination shows an <fact6>increased anteroposterior chest diameter</fact6> and <fact7>coarse crackles in the lower lung fields bilaterally</fact7>. Treatment with a drug that directly antagonizes the effects of <fact8>vagal stimulation on the airways</fact8> is begun. Which of the following drugs was most likely started?

Answer: The patient has a <fact2>history of chronic bronchitis</fact2> and is experiencing <fact3>1-month history of worsening shortness of breath and cough productive of thick sputum</fact3>. His physical examination reveals <fact6>increased anteroposterior chest diameter</fact6> and <fact7>coarse crackles in the lower lung fields bilaterally</fact7>, which are indicative of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The treatment with a drug that directly antagonizes the effects of <fact8>vagal stimulation on the airways</fact8> suggests the use of an anticholinergic agent. Among the options provided, Tiotropium is an anticholinergic drug that directly antagonizes the effects of vagal stimulation on the airways, making it the most likely started treatment for this patient.

question:
An otherwise healthy 49-year-old woman has a routine full blood count complete prior her elective cholecystectomy. The lab test results are as follows:
Laboratory test
Hemoglobin
12.1 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)
85 μm3
Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC)
47%
Reticulocyte count
3.4 %
White blood cell count
9700/mm3
Platelet count
229,000/mm3
A peripheral blood smear reveals spherocytes. The Coombs test is negative. The physical examination is remarkable for scleral icterus and moderate splenomegaly. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test of this patient’s underlying disorder?
A) Eosin-5-maleimide binding test
B) Flow cytometry for CD55/CD59
C) Anti parvovirus B19 antibodies
D) Bone marrow biopsy
E) Liver function tests
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>49-year-old woman</fact1> has a routine full blood count complete prior her elective <fact2>cholecystectomy</fact2>. The lab test results are as follows:
Laboratory test
Hemoglobin <fact3>12.1 g/dL</fact3>
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) <fact4>85 μm3</fact4>
Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) <fact5>47%</fact5>
Reticulocyte count <fact6>3.4%</fact6>
White blood cell count <fact7>9700/mm3</fact7>
Platelet count <fact8>229,000/mm3</fact8>
A peripheral blood smear reveals <fact9>spherocytes</fact9>. The <fact10>Coombs test</fact10> is <fact11>negative</fact11>. The physical examination is remarkable for <fact12>scleral icterus</fact12> and <fact13>moderate splenomegaly</fact13>. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test of this patient’s underlying disorder?

Answer: Considering the patient's presentation, the laboratory results show a <fact3>hemoglobin level of 12.1 g/dL</fact3>, which is below the normal range, indicating anemia. The <fact4>MCV of 85 μm3</fact4> is within the normal range, but the <fact5>MCHC of 47%</fact5> is below the normal range, suggesting a decrease in hemoglobin concentration within the red blood cells. The <fact6>reticulocyte count of 3.4%</fact6> is within the normal range, indicating that the bone marrow is not producing red blood cells at an increased rate. The presence of <fact9>spherocytes</fact9> on the peripheral blood smear is indicative of spherocytosis, a condition characterized by the production of abnormal red blood cells that are prone to destruction. The <fact10>negative Coombs test</fact10> rules out autoimmune hemolytic anemia. The physical examination findings of <fact12>scleral icterus</fact12> and <fact13>moderate splenomegaly</fact13> suggest hemolysis and splenic involvement, respectively. Given these factors, the most appropriate diagnostic test is flow cytometry for CD55/CD59, which is used to diagnose hereditary spherocytosis, a genetic disorder characterized by the production of abnormal red blood cells. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 14-year-old girl comes to the physician because she has not yet had her period. She is at the 10th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. Examination shows a broad chest with widely spaced nipples, a low posterior hairline, forearms angled 20° away from the body when fully extended, and shortened fourth metacarpals bilaterally. Sexual development is Tanner stage 1. Which of the following statements about this patient's fertility is most accurate?
A) Pregnancy success rate with donor oocytes is similar to patients with primary ovarian failure
B) Administration of gonadotropins will increase the chances of conceiving
C) Impaired tubal ciliary function will prevent natural fertilization
D) The majority of patients become pregnant without medical assistance
E) Functional gametes and the absence of a uterus make surrogacy necessary
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>14-year-old girl</fact1> comes to the physician because she has not yet had her period. She is at the 10th percentile for <fact2>height</fact2> and 25th percentile for <fact3>weight</fact3>. Examination shows a <fact4>broad chest with widely spaced nipples</fact4>, a <fact5>low posterior hairline</fact5>, <fact6>forearms angled 20° away from the body when fully extended</fact6>, and <fact7>shortened fourth metacarpals bilaterally</fact7>. <fact8>Sexual development is Tanner stage 1</fact8>. Which of the following statements about this patient's <fact9>fertility</fact9> is most accurate?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation, the <fact1>14-year-old girl</fact1> with primary amenorrhea and <fact2>short stature</fact2> (10th percentile for height) is likely affected by Turner syndrome, a genetic disorder characterized by the presence of only one X chromosome (45,X). Key features of Turner syndrome include a broad chest with widely spaced nipples (<fact4>broad chest with widely spaced nipples</fact4>), a low posterior hairline (<fact5>low posterior hairline</fact5>), forearms angled away from the body when fully extended (<fact6>forearms angled 20° away from the body when fully extended</fact6>), and shortened fourth metacarpals bilaterally (<fact7>shortened fourth metacarpals bilaterally</fact7>). Individuals with Turner syndrome typically have impaired ovarian function and are often infertile due to the absence or underdevelopment of ovaries. 

The statement about the patient's fertility that is most accurate is {C} Impaired tubal ciliary function will prevent natural fertilization. This is because the majority of women with Turner syndrome have streak ovaries or rudimentary ovaries, which are unable to produce functional gametes. As a result, natural conception is not possible. While assisted reproductive technologies, such as in vitro fertilization (IVF) using donor oocytes, can help women with Turner syndrome achieve pregnancy, the use of a surrogate is not necessary due to the absence of a uterus, but rather because the patient's ovaries are not producing functional gametes.

question:
A 42-year-old man presents to your office complaining of right-sided facial swelling that has progressively worsened over the last month after returning from a trip to India. On examination, the patient has an obvious distortion of the facial features on the right without erythema or lymphadenopathy. A neurological exam reveals no deficits. His blood pressure is 115/80 mm Hg, heart rate is 65/min, and the temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F). The patient states that he has been having trouble chewing his food, but is not experiencing any pain. The patient is up to date on all of his immunizations. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his facial swelling?
A) Benign cystic tumor with stroma resembling lymph node tissue
B) Benign salivary gland tumor composed of stromal and epithelial tissue
C) An infection with paramyxovirus
D) Malignant tumor composed of squamous and mucinous cells
E) Sialolithiasis that has progressed to a S. aureus infection
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>42-year-old man</fact1> presents to your office complaining of <fact2>right-sided facial swelling</fact2> that has progressively worsened over the last <fact3>month</fact3> after returning from a trip to <fact4>India</fact4>. On examination, the patient has an obvious distortion of the facial features on the right without <fact5>erythema or lymphadenopathy</fact5>. A neurological exam reveals no deficits. His <fact6>blood pressure is 115/80 mm Hg</fact6>, <fact7>heart rate is 65/min</fact7>, and the <fact8>temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F)</fact8>. The patient states that he has been having trouble chewing his food, but is not experiencing any <fact9>pain</fact9>. The patient is up to date on all of his <fact10>immunizations</fact10>. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his <fact11>facial swelling</fact11>?

A) <fact12>Benign cystic tumor with stroma resembling lymph node tissue</fact12>
B) <fact13>Benign salivary gland tumor composed of stromal and epithelial tissue</fact13>
C) <fact14>An infection with paramyxovirus</fact14>
D) <fact15>Malignant tumor composed of squamous and mucinous cells</fact15>
E) <fact16>Sialolithiasis that has progressed to a S. aureus infection</fact16>

Answer: 
Based on the provided information, the patient has been experiencing <fact2>right-sided facial swelling</fact2> without <fact5>erythema or lymphadenopathy</fact5>, which suggests a localized rather than a systemic infection. The patient's <fact9>absence of pain</fact9> and the fact that he is up to date on all of his <fact10>immunizations</fact10> reduce the likelihood of an infectious cause such as <fact14>An infection with paramyxovirus</fact14>. The patient's symptoms of <fact2>right-sided facial swelling</fact2> that has progressively worsened over the last <fact3>month</fact3> after returning from a trip to <fact4>India</fact4> may be related to a benign salivary gland tumor, which is a common cause of facial swelling in this region. Therefore, the most likely cause of his facial swelling is a <fact13>benign salivary gland tumor composed of stromal and epithelial tissue</fact13>.

question:
A microbiologist is studying the emergence of a virulent strain of the virus. After a detailed study of the virus and its life cycle, he proposes a theory: Initially, a host cell is co-infected with 2 viruses from the same virus family. Within the host cell, concomitant production of various genome segments from both viruses occurs. Ultimately, the different genome segments from the viruses are packaged into a unique and novel virus particle. The newly formed virus particle is both stable and viable and is a new strain from the virus family that caused the outbreak of infection. Which of the following viruses is capable of undergoing the above-mentioned process?
A) Cytomegalovirus
B) Epstein-Barr virus
C) Human immunodeficiency virus
D) Rotavirus
E) Vaccinia virus
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>microbiologist</fact1> is studying the emergence of a <fact2>virulent strain</fact2> of the <fact3>virus</fact3>. After a <fact4>detailed study</fact4> of the <fact3>virus</fact3> and its <fact5>life cycle</fact5>, he proposes a <fact6>theory</fact6>: Initially, a <fact7>host cell</fact7> is <fact8>co-infected</fact8> with 2 <fact9>viruses</fact9> from the same <fact10>virus family</fact10>. Within the <fact7>host cell</fact7>, <fact11>concomitant production</fact11> of various <fact12>genome segments</fact12> from both <fact9>viruses</fact9> occurs. Ultimately, the different <fact12>genome segments</fact12> from the <fact9>viruses</fact9> are <fact13>packaged</fact13> into a <fact14>unique</fact14> and <fact15>novel</fact15> <fact16>virus particle</fact16>. The <fact17>newly formed</fact17> <fact16>virus particle</fact16> is both <fact18>stable</fact18> and <fact19>viable</fact19> and is a <fact20>new strain</fact20> from the <fact10>virus family</fact10> that caused the <fact21>outbreak of infection</fact21>. Which of the following <fact22>viruses</fact22> is capable of undergoing the above-mentioned process?

Answer: The process described in the question is a recombination event between two viruses from the same family, resulting in a new strain. This process is characteristic of viruses that have a segmented genome, allowing for the exchange of genome segments between different viral particles. Among the options provided, the virus that is capable of undergoing this process is the <fact22>virus</fact22> that has a segmented genome, which is the <fact23>Rotavirus</fact23>.

question:
A one-week-old boy presents with yellow sclerae, severe lethargy, and decreased muscle tone. His mother notes that the symptoms started shortly after birth and have been progressively worsening. The patient is breast fed and takes no medications. His labs are within normal limits with the exception of his liver function tests as follows:

ALT: 8 U/ L
AST: 10 U/L
Alkaline phosphatase: 50 U/L
Albumin: 3.7 g/dL
Total protein: 6.7 g/dL
Bilirubin, total: 29.4 mg/dL
Bilirubin, unconjugated: 29.2 mg/dL
Bilirubin, conjugated: 0.2 mg/dL

The boy is taken immediately for treatment. What is the most likely underlying cause of his condition?
A) Deficiency in glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase
B) Absence of UDP-glucuronosyltransferase-1A1
C) Alteration in the ankyrin protein
D) Reduction in UDP-glucuronosyltransferase-1A1 activity
E) Deficiency in glucocerebrosidase
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>one-week-old boy</fact1> presents with <fact2>yellow sclerae</fact2>, <fact3>severe lethargy</fact3>, and <fact4>decreased muscle tone</fact4>. His mother notes that the symptoms started shortly after <fact5>birth</fact5> and have been progressively worsening. The patient is <fact6>breast fed</fact6> and takes no medications. His labs are within normal limits with the exception of his <fact7>liver function tests</fact7> as follows:
<fact8>ALT: 8 U/ L</fact8>
<fact9>AST: 10 U/L</fact9>
<fact10>Alkaline phosphatase: 50 U/L</fact10>
<fact11>Albumin: 3.7 g/dL</fact11>
<fact12>Total protein: 6.7 g/dL</fact12>
<fact13>Bilirubin, total: 29.4 mg/dL</fact13>
<fact14>Bilirubin, unconjugated: 29.2 mg/dL</fact14>
<fact15>Bilirubin, conjugated: 0.2 mg/dL</fact15>
The boy is taken immediately for treatment. What is the most likely underlying cause of his condition?

Relevant key phrases: 
* <fact2>yellow sclerae</fact2>
* <fact3>severe lethargy</fact3>
* <fact4>decreased muscle tone</fact4>
* <fact7>liver function tests</fact7>
* <fact13>Bilirubin, total: 29.4 mg/dL</fact13>
* <fact14>Bilirubin, unconjugated: 29.2 mg/dL</fact14>
* <fact15>Bilirubin, conjugated: 0.2 mg/dL</fact15>

Answer: 
The patient's presentation of <fact2>yellow sclerae</fact2>, <fact3>severe lethargy</fact3>, and <fact4>decreased muscle tone</fact4> is suggestive of <fact16>neonatal jaundice</fact16>. The elevated <fact13>Bilirubin, total: 29.4 mg/dL</fact13> and <fact14>Bilirubin, unconjugated: 29.2 mg/dL</fact14> with a very low <fact15>Bilirubin, conjugated: 0.2 mg/dL</fact15> indicates a predominance of unconjugated bilirubin. This pattern is consistent with <fact17>breast milk jaundice</fact17>, which is a common cause of neonatal jaundice. The most likely underlying cause of this condition is a <fact18>reduction in UDP-glucuronosyltransferase-1A1 activity</fact18>, which is a key enzyme responsible for the conjugation of bilirubin. This reduction in enzyme activity leads to the accumulation of unconjugated bilirubin, resulting in the observed symptoms.

question:
Thirty minutes after delivery, a 3600-g (7-lb 15-oz) newborn has noisy breathing, bluish discoloration of her lips, and intermittent respiratory distress. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation and required bag-mask resuscitation immediately after delivery. Pregnancy was uncomplicated. Her mother has noticed the bluish lip discoloration worsen when she fed and improve when she cried. The patient's pulse is 163/min, respirations are 62/min, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. The crying infant's lungs are clear to auscultation. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
A) Diffuse reticulogranular densities on chest x-ray
B) Boot-shaped heart on chest x-ray
C) Passage of a gastric catheter through the mouth not possible
D) Passage of a catheter through the nasal cavity not possible
E) Scaphoid abdomen
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>3600-g (7-lb 15-oz) newborn</fact1> has <fact2>noisy breathing, bluish discoloration of her lips, and intermittent respiratory distress</fact2> thirty minutes after delivery. She was born at <fact3>38 weeks' gestation</fact3> and required <fact4>bag-mask resuscitation immediately after delivery</fact4>. Pregnancy was <fact5>uncomplicated</fact5>. Her mother has noticed the <fact6>bluish lip discoloration worsen when she fed and improve when she cried</fact6>. The patient's <fact7>pulse is 163/min</fact7>, <fact8>respirations are 62/min</fact8>, and <fact9>blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg</fact9>. The crying infant's <fact10>lungs are clear to auscultation</fact10>. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

Answer: C) Passage of a gastric catheter through the mouth not possible.

The patient's symptoms of <fact2>noisy breathing, bluish discoloration of her lips, and intermittent respiratory distress</fact2> thirty minutes after delivery, along with the need for <fact4>bag-mask resuscitation immediately after delivery</fact4>, suggest respiratory distress. The fact that the <fact6>bluish lip discoloration worsens when she fed and improves when she cried</fact6> indicates that the condition is exacerbated by feeding and improved by crying, which is consistent with a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH). However, CDH is typically associated with a scaphoid abdomen, which is not mentioned in the question. 

Given the context of the question, the correct answer is more likely related to the symptoms and the complications of the respiratory distress. The passage of a gastric catheter through the mouth not possible (option C) is not directly related to the symptoms. However, it is related to the symptoms if we consider that the infant has a condition that affects the passage of a gastric catheter through the mouth, such as esophageal atresia. The esophageal atresia is a congenital condition where the esophagus is not fully developed, and it is often associated with respiratory distress. This condition is often diagnosed with a contrast study or an upper GI series, but the passage of a gastric catheter through the mouth not possible is a symptom that can be related to this condition.

question:
A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of persistent fatigue for the past 4 months. She has no history of major medical illness. Her temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 121/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae. A peripheral blood smear is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
A) Hereditary spherocytosis
B) Vitamin B12 deficiency
C) Pyruvate kinase deficiency
D) Iron deficiency
E) β-thalassemia minor
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>24-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>persistent fatigue for the past 4 months</fact2>. She has no history of major medical illness. Her <fact3>temperature is 36°C (96.8°F)</fact3>, <fact4>pulse is 121/min</fact4>, and <fact5>blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg</fact5>. Physical examination shows <fact6>pale conjunctivae</fact6>. A <fact7>peripheral blood smear is shown</fact7>. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

Answer: Given the <fact1>24-year-old woman's</fact1> symptoms of <fact2>persistent fatigue for the past 4 months</fact2>, along with the physical examination finding of <fact6>pale conjunctivae</fact6>, it is likely that she is experiencing anemia. The patient's <fact4>pulse is 121/min</fact4>, which is elevated, suggesting an attempt by the body to compensate for decreased oxygen delivery to tissues. The <fact7>peripheral blood smear</fact7> would provide further information about the type of anemia, but based on the information provided, the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is <fact5>iron deficiency</fact5>, which is the most common cause of anemia in the general population and is characterized by fatigue, pallor, and elevated pulse.

question:
A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department with acute shortness of breath that developed after a 10-hour international flight. His pulse is 124/min and pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 90%. He weighs 50-kg (110-lb). A diagnosis of pulmonary embolism is suspected and intravenous heparin is initiated. If the volume of distribution of heparin is equivalent to 60 mL/kg and the target peak plasma concentration is 0.5 units/mL, which of the following is the most appropriate loading dose for this patient?
A) 3,000 units
B) 1,500 units
C) 6,000 units
D) Cannot be calculated, as bioavailability is not known
E) 30 units
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>35-year-old man</fact1> comes to the emergency department with <fact2>acute shortness of breath</fact2> that developed after a <fact3>10-hour international flight</fact3>. His <fact4>pulse is 124/min</fact4> and <fact5>pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 90%</fact5>. He weighs <fact6>50-kg (110-lb)</fact6>. A diagnosis of <fact7>pulmonary embolism</fact7> is suspected and intravenous <fact8>heparin</fact8> is initiated. If the <fact9>volume of distribution of heparin</fact9> is equivalent to <fact10>60 mL/kg</fact10> and the <fact11>target peak plasma concentration</fact11> is <fact12>0.5 units/mL</fact12>, which of the following is the most appropriate <fact13>loading dose</fact13> for this patient?

Answer: To determine the most appropriate loading dose for this patient, we can use the formula for calculating the loading dose:

Loading dose = Desired peak plasma concentration x Volume of distribution

Given that the target peak plasma concentration is 0.5 units/mL and the volume of distribution is 60 mL/kg, we can calculate the loading dose as follows:

Loading dose = 0.5 units/mL x 60 mL/kg
Loading dose = 30 units/kg

Since the patient weighs 50 kg, we can multiply the loading dose per kilogram by the patient's weight to determine the total loading dose:

Total loading dose = 30 units/kg x 50 kg
Total loading dose = 1,500 units

Therefore, the most appropriate loading dose for this patient is 1,500 units.

question:
A 29-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. On presentation, he is found to have scalp and trunk lacerations that are still actively bleeding. He has no past medical history and does not take any medications. On presentation, his temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 110/74 mmHg, pulse is 82/min, and respirations are 17/min. On physical exam, he is found to be anxious but does not have any visible injuries other than the lacerations. Which of the following processes would most likely be seen in this patient?
A) Baroreceptor-mediated vasodilation
B) Chemoreceptor-mediated vasoconstriction
C) Increased acetylcholine at the sinoatrial node
D) Increased atrial natriuretic peptide release
E) Increased norepinephrine at the sinoatrial node
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>29-year-old man</fact1> presents to the emergency department after a <fact2>motor vehicle accident</fact2>. On presentation, he is found to have <fact3>scalp and trunk lacerations</fact3> that are still actively bleeding. He has no <fact4>past medical history</fact4> and does not take any <fact5>medications</fact5>. On presentation, his <fact6>temperature is 98.6°F (37°C)</fact6>, <fact7>blood pressure is 110/74 mmHg</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 82/min</fact8>, and <fact9>respirations are 17/min</fact9>. On physical exam, he is found to be <fact10>anxious</fact10> but does not have any visible injuries other than the <fact11>lacerations</fact11>. Which of the following processes would most likely be seen in this patient?

Answer: Evaluating the patient's presentation, the <fact1>29-year-old man</fact1> who has experienced a <fact2>motor vehicle accident</fact2> is found to have <fact3>scalp and trunk lacerations</fact3> that are still actively bleeding. He is also <fact10>anxious</fact10> but does not have any other visible injuries. In this situation, the body's response to the injury and stress would involve the activation of the sympathetic nervous system to increase heart rate, blood pressure, and cardiac output to maintain blood flow to the injured areas. The increased <fact8>pulse of 82/min</fact8> and <fact7>blood pressure of 110/74 mmHg</fact7> indicate an elevated sympathetic tone. Therefore, the process that would most likely be seen in this patient is the release of <fact12>norepinephrine</fact12> at the sinoatrial node, leading to increased heart rate and cardiac output. This is consistent with the body's "fight or flight" response to stress and injury. The answer is {E}.

question:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of headaches for the past 2 weeks. His headaches tend to occur in the morning and are associated with nausea and vomiting. One month ago, the patient was admitted to the hospital because of fever, irritability, and neck rigidity, and he was successfully treated with antibiotics. His temperature today is 37.5°C (98.5°F). An MRI of the brain shows bilateral ventricular enlargement and enlargement of the subarachnoid space. Which of the following is the most likely explanation of the patient's condition?
A) Increased CSF production by the choroid plexus
B) Impaired CSF flow through the arachnoid granulations
C) Impaired CSF drainage into the subarachnoid space
D) Impaired CSF drainage into the fourth ventricle
E) Compensatory enlargement of CSF spaces
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>8-year-old boy</fact1> is brought to the physician because of <fact2>headaches</fact2> for the past <fact3>2 weeks</fact3>. His headaches tend to occur in the morning and are associated with <fact4>nausea and vomiting</fact4>. One month ago, the patient was admitted to the hospital because of <fact5>fever, irritability, and neck rigidity</fact5>, and he was successfully treated with <fact6>antibiotics</fact6>. His temperature today is <fact7>37.5°C (98.5°F)</fact7>. An <fact8>MRI of the brain</fact8> shows <fact9>bilateral ventricular enlargement</fact9> and <fact10>enlargement of the subarachnoid space</fact10>. Which of the following is the most likely explanation of the patient's condition?

Answer: The patient's presentation of <fact2>headaches</fact2> for the past <fact3>2 weeks</fact3> associated with <fact4>nausea and vomiting</fact4> suggests an issue with increased intracranial pressure. The patient's recent history of <fact5>fever, irritability, and neck rigidity</fact5> treated with <fact6>antibiotics</fact6> indicates a possible infection that could have led to complications such as meningitis. The <fact8>MRI of the brain</fact8> showing <fact9>bilateral ventricular enlargement</fact9> and <fact10>enlargement of the subarachnoid space</fact10> is consistent with hydrocephalus, which is often caused by impaired CSF drainage. Considering the patient's history and the MRI findings, the most likely explanation of the patient's condition is impaired CSF drainage into the subarachnoid space, which is a common complication of meningitis. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 25-year-old, G2P2L2 woman presents with a complaint of missed menstrual cycle for 4 weeks. Her previous menstrual cycles were regular, occurring every 28–35 days consistently. The patient does not have any other complaints currently. Her past medical history reveals two uncomplicated and normal vaginal deliveries at term. She has a 2-year-old boy and a 6-month-old girl. The patient and her partner use the withdrawal method for contraception. The urine pregnancy test result is positive. The patient returns to the clinic after 1 week expressing her desire to discontinue with the pregnancy and inquires about the possibility of an elective abortion. Which of the following procedures is the most appropriate for elective termination of pregnancy in this patient?
A) Dilatation and evacuation (D&E)
B) Oxytocin-induced labor
C) Manual uterine aspiration
D) Dilatation and curettage (D & C) after vacuum evacuation
E) Oral mifepristone + misoprostol
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>25-year-old, G2P2L2 woman</fact1> presents with a complaint of <fact2>missed menstrual cycle for 4 weeks</fact2>. Her previous menstrual cycles were <fact3>regular, occurring every 28–35 days consistently</fact3>. The patient does not have any other complaints currently. Her <fact4>past medical history reveals two uncomplicated and normal vaginal deliveries at term</fact4>. She has a <fact5>2-year-old boy and a 6-month-old girl</fact5>. The patient and her partner use the <fact6>withdrawal method for contraception</fact6>. The <fact7>urine pregnancy test result is positive</fact7>. The patient returns to the clinic after <fact8>1 week expressing her desire to discontinue with the pregnancy and inquires about the possibility of an elective abortion</fact8>. Which of the following procedures is the most appropriate for elective termination of pregnancy in this patient?

Answer: 
The patient is <fact1>25 years old</fact1> and <fact2>desires to terminate her pregnancy</fact2>. She has a <fact3>previous history of two uncomplicated vaginal deliveries</fact3>, indicating that she has had a previous uterine scar. Given this history, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) recommends avoiding procedures that could potentially disrupt the uterine scar, such as vacuum aspiration or manual uterine aspiration. A more appropriate option for this patient would be <fact4>dilatation and evacuation (D&E)</fact4>, which is a procedure that is typically performed under general anesthesia and involves the use of a suction curette to remove the products of conception. This procedure is often preferred for patients with a previous uterine scar due to its lower risk of complications. Therefore, the most appropriate procedure for this patient is <fact5>dilatation and evacuation (D&E)</fact5>.

question:
A obstetrician is working in a developing country to help promote maternal health and fetal well being. While there, he delivers a baby who he suspects has congenital hypothyroidism, most likely caused by inadequate maternal iodine intake. Which of the following signs and symptoms would NOT be expected to be observed in this child?
A) Hypotonia
B) Diarrhea
C) Umbilical hernia
D) Mild jaundice
E) Macroglossia
answer:
Reformatted Question: A obstetrician is working in a developing country to help promote maternal health and fetal well being. While there, he delivers a baby who he suspects has congenital hypothyroidism, most likely caused by inadequate maternal iodine intake. Which of the following signs and symptoms would NOT be expected to be observed in this child?

A) Hypotonia
B) Diarrhea
C) Umbilical hernia
D) Mild jaundice
E) Macroglossia

Answer: E) Macroglossia

Explanation: Congenital hypothyroidism is a condition where the thyroid gland is underdeveloped or not functioning properly, leading to a deficiency of thyroid hormones. This condition can cause a variety of signs and symptoms, including hypotonia (A), umbilical hernia (C), and mild jaundice (D). However, macroglossia (E), or an enlarged tongue, is not typically associated with congenital hypothyroidism. In fact, the most common signs and symptoms of congenital hypothyroidism include hypotonia, umbilical hernia, and jaundice, as well as other signs such as a large fontanelle, dry skin, and a poor response to stimuli. Macroglossia is more commonly associated with other conditions, such as Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome or Down syndrome. Therefore, macroglossia is the correct answer.

question:
A 23-year-old man presents to the office for a circular, itchy rash over the abdomen that has been slowly getting worse for the past 2 weeks. The patient has a medical history of chronic dermatitis and chronic sinusitis for which he has prescriptions of topical hydrocortisone and fexofenadine. He smokes one-half pack of cigarettes every day. His vital signs include: blood pressure 128/76 mm Hg, heart rate 78/min, and respirations 12/min. On physical examination, the patient appears tired but oriented. Examination of the skin reveals a 2 x 2 cm round and erythematous, annular plaque on the abdomen 3 cm to the left of the umbilicus. There are no vesicles, pustules, or papules. Auscultation of the heart reveals a 1/6 systolic murmur. Breath sounds are mildly coarse at the bases. A KOH preparation from the skin scraping confirms the presence of hyphae. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
A) Itraconazole
B) Griseofulvin
C) Topical clobetasol
D) Topical clindamycin
E) Doxycycline
answer:

The patient has a medical history of <fact5>chronic dermatitis</fact5> and <fact6>chronic sinusitis</fact6> for which he has prescriptions of <fact7>topical hydrocortisone</fact7> and <fact8>fexofenadine</fact8>. He <fact9>smokes one-half pack of cigarettes every day</fact9>. His vital signs include: <fact10>blood pressure 128/76 mm Hg</fact10>, <fact11>heart rate 78/min</fact11>, and <fact12>respirations 12/min</fact12>. On physical examination, the patient appears <fact13>tired but oriented</fact13>. Examination of the skin reveals a <fact14>2 x 2 cm round and erythematous, annular plaque</fact14> on the <fact15>abdomen</fact15> <fact16>3 cm to the left of the umbilicus</fact16>. There are no <fact17>vesicles</fact17>, <fact18>pustules</fact18>, or <fact19>papules</fact19>. Auscultation of the heart reveals a <fact20>1/6 systolic murmur</fact20>. Breath sounds are <fact21>mildly coarse at the bases</fact21>. A <fact22>KOH preparation from the skin scraping confirms the presence of <fact23>hyphae</fact23>. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

Answer: The patient presents with a <fact2>circular, itchy rash</fact2> over the <fact3>abdomen</fact3> that has been slowly getting worse for the past <fact4>2 weeks</fact4>, which is indicative of a fungal infection. The presence of <fact23>hyphae</fact23> in the KOH preparation further supports this diagnosis. The patient's medical history of <fact5>chronic dermatitis</fact5> and <fact6>chronic sinusitis</fact6> may indicate a predisposition to fungal infections. Given the presence of <fact23>hyphae</fact23> and the patient's symptoms, the next best step in management would be to initiate antifungal therapy. Among the options provided, <fact24>Itraconazole</fact24> is an oral antifungal medication that is effective against a wide range of fungal infections, including those caused by dermatophytes. Therefore, the next best step in the management of this patient is to prescribe <fact24>Itraconazole</fact24>.

question:
A 9-month-old boy is brought to his pediatrician by his mother for a routine health checkup. The boy was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. He is up to date on all vaccines and is meeting all developmental milestones. He was breastfed for the first 3 months and then switched to cow’s milk and about two months ago she started giving him fruits and vegetables. Family history is noncontributory. Today, his heart rate is 120/min, respiratory rate is 40/min, blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg, and temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F). On examination, he has a heartbeat with a regular rate and rhythm and his lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Generally, the boy looks pale. His weight and height fall within the expected range. A complete blood count (CBC) shows the following:
Hemoglobin (Hb): 9.1 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV): 65 fL
Total iron binding capacity (TIBC): 550 μg/dL
Serum iron: 45 µg/dL
Serum lead: < 5 µg/dL
What is the best treatment for this patient?
A) Iron supplementation only
B) Proper diet and iron supplementation
C) Multivitamins
D) Proper diet only
E) Lead chelation therapy
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>9-month-old boy</fact1> is brought to his pediatrician by his mother for a routine health checkup. The boy was born at <fact2>39 weeks gestation</fact2> via spontaneous vaginal delivery. He is up to date on all <fact3>vaccines</fact3> and is meeting all <fact4>developmental milestones</fact4>. He was <fact5>breastfed for the first 3 months</fact5> and then switched to <fact6>cow’s milk</fact6> and about two months ago she started giving him <fact7>fruits and vegetables</fact7>. Family history is <fact8>noncontributory</fact8>. Today, his <fact9>heart rate is 120/min</fact9>, <fact10>respiratory rate is 40/min</fact10>, <fact11>blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg</fact11>, and <fact12>temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F)</fact12>. On examination, he has a <fact13>heartbeat with a regular rate and rhythm</fact13> and his <fact14>lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally</fact14>. Generally, the boy looks <fact15>pale</fact15>. His <fact16>weight and height fall within the expected range</fact16>. A <fact17>complete blood count (CBC)</fact17> shows the following:
<fact18>Hemoglobin (Hb): 9.1 g/dL</fact18>
<fact19>Mean corpuscular volume (MCV): 65 fL</fact19>
<fact20>Total iron binding capacity (TIBC): 550 μg/dL</fact20>
<fact21>Serum iron: 45 µg/dL</fact21>
<fact22>Serum lead: < 5 µg/dL</fact22>
What is the best treatment for this patient?

Answer: 
B) Proper diet and iron supplementation

Explanation:
The patient, a <fact1>9-month-old boy</fact1>, has a <fact18>Hemoglobin (Hb) level of 9.1 g/dL</fact18>, which is lower than the normal range for his age. This indicates anemia. The <fact19>Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) is 65 fL</fact19>, which is below the normal range, indicating microcytic anemia. The <fact20>Total iron binding capacity (TIBC) is elevated at 550 μg/dL</fact20>, and the <fact21>Serum iron is low at 45 µg/dL</fact21>, suggesting iron deficiency anemia. The patient's <fact22>Serum lead level is normal</fact22>, which rules out lead poisoning as a cause of anemia. Given the patient's age and the diagnosis of iron deficiency anemia, the best treatment is a combination of <fact7>proper diet</fact7> and <fact23>iron supplementation</fact23>.

question:
A 60-year-old man with a long-standing history of chronic hepatitis C infection comes to the emergency department because of abdominal distention and scleral icterus for the past month. His heart rate is 76/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), and blood pressure is 110/86 mm Hg. Physical examination show signs suggestive of liver cirrhosis. Which of the following signs is a direct result of hyperestrinism in cirrhotic patients?
A) Coagulopathy
B) Gynecomastia
C) Jaundice
D) Lower limb swelling
E) Caput medusae
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>60-year-old man</fact1> with a long-standing history of <fact2>chronic hepatitis C infection</fact2> comes to the emergency department because of <fact3>abdominal distention</fact3> and <fact4>scleral icterus</fact4> for the past <fact5>month</fact5>. His <fact6>heart rate is 76/min</fact6>, <fact7>respiratory rate is 14/min</fact7>, <fact8>temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F)</fact8>, and <fact9>blood pressure is 110/86 mm Hg</fact9>. Physical examination show signs suggestive of <fact10>liver cirrhosis</fact10>. Which of the following signs is a direct result of <fact11>hyperestrinism</fact11> in <fact12>cirrhotic patients</fact12>?

Answer: B) Gynecomastia

The question mentions that the patient has a long-standing history of <fact2>chronic hepatitis C infection</fact2> and physical examination shows signs suggestive of <fact10>liver cirrhosis</fact10>. Liver cirrhosis is associated with hormonal imbalances, including <fact11>hyperestrinism</fact11>. Hyperestrinism refers to an excess of estrogen in the body. In cirrhotic patients, the liver's inability to metabolize estrogen leads to an accumulation of estrogen, resulting in <fact11>hyperestrinism</fact11>. One of the direct results of <fact11>hyperestrinism</fact11> in <fact12>cirrhotic patients</fact12> is the development of <fact13>gynecomastia</fact13>, which is the enlargement of breast tissue in males. This is a common symptom of liver cirrhosis and is often seen in patients with chronic liver disease.

question:
A 55-year-old man presents with a 2-month history of an increasing sensation of fullness in the upper left side of his abdomen. He complains of increasing fatigue and dyspnea. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 125/70 mm Hg. His conjunctivae are pale. The examination of the heart and lungs shows no abnormalities. The splenic margin is palpable 8 cm (3.1 in) below the costal margin. No abnormal lymph nodes are found. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 8 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 90 μm3
Leukocyte count 3,000/mm3
Platelet count 85,000/mm3
Peripheral blood smear shows small lymphocytes with cell membrane projections. Bone marrow aspiration is unsuccessful. Cell immunophenotyping is positive for CD25. Which of the following is the most effective pharmacotherapy at this time?
A) Cladribine
B) Fludarabine
C) Imatinib
D) Prednisone
E) Thalidomide
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>55-year-old man</fact1> presents with a <fact2>2-month history</fact2> of an increasing sensation of <fact3>fullness in the upper left side of his abdomen</fact3>. He complains of increasing <fact4>fatigue and dyspnea</fact4>. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His <fact5>temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F)</fact5>, <fact6>pulse is 90/min</fact6>, <fact7>respiratory rate is 18/min</fact7>, and <fact8>blood pressure is 125/70 mm Hg</fact8>. His <fact9>conjunctivae are pale</fact9>. The examination of the heart and lungs shows no abnormalities. The <fact10>splenic margin is palpable 8 cm (3.1 in) below the costal margin</fact10>. No abnormal lymph nodes are found. Laboratory studies show:
<fact11>Hemoglobin 8 g/dL</fact11>
<fact12>Mean corpuscular volume 90 μm3</fact12>
<fact13>Leukocyte count 3,000/mm3</fact13>
<fact14>Platelet count 85,000/mm3</fact14>
<fact15>Peripheral blood smear shows small lymphocytes with cell membrane projections</fact15>. <fact16>Bone marrow aspiration is unsuccessful</fact16>. <fact17>Cell immunophenotyping is positive for CD25</fact17>. Which of the following is the most effective pharmacotherapy at this time? 

Options: 
(A) Cladribine
(B) Fludarabine
(C) Imatinib
(D) Prednisone
(E) Thalidomide

Answer:
The patient's presentation of <fact1>increasing sensation of fullness in the upper left side of his abdomen</fact1> and <fact4>fatigue and dyspnea</fact4> over a <fact2>2-month history</fact2> suggests a possible diagnosis of splenic enlargement, which is confirmed by the palpable <fact10>splenic margin 8 cm (3.1 in) below the costal margin</fact10>. The patient's <fact5>low hemoglobin of 8 g/dL</fact5> and <fact13>low leukocyte count of 3,000/mm3</fact13> indicate a possible bone marrow disorder. The <fact15>peripheral blood smear showing small lymphocytes with cell membrane projections</fact15> and <fact17>cell immunophenotyping positive for CD25</fact17> suggest a diagnosis of hairy cell leukemia, a rare type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow. 

The most effective pharmacotherapy for hairy cell leukemia is <fact18>cladribine</fact18>, a chemotherapy medication that has been shown to be highly effective in treating this condition. Cladribine works by interfering with the growth of cancer cells, ultimately leading to their death. It has been shown to improve survival rates and quality of life in patients with hairy cell leukemia. 

Therefore, the most effective pharmacotherapy at this time is <fact19>cladribine</fact19>.

question:
An 18-year-old male presents to the emergency department trauma bay with a gunshot wound to the abdomen. The patient undergoes an exploratory laparotomy, during which, it is discovered that his splenic artery was damaged at its origin from the celiac trunk. The surgeon ligates the splenic artery at its origin. Which of the following arteries will now be hypoperfused as a result?
A) Left gastric artery
B) Gastroduodenal artery
C) Right gastroepiploic artery
D) Left gastroepiploic artery
E) Common hepatic artery
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>18-year-old male</fact1> presents to the emergency department trauma bay with a <fact2>gunshot wound to the abdomen</fact2>. The patient undergoes an <fact3>exploratory laparotomy</fact3>, during which, it is discovered that his <fact4>splenic artery</fact4> was damaged at its <fact5>origin from the celiac trunk</fact5>. The surgeon <fact6>ligates the splenic artery at its origin</fact6>. Which of the following arteries will now be <fact7>hypoperfused as a result</fact7>?

A) <fact8>Left gastric artery</fact8>
B) <fact9>Gastroduodenal artery</fact9>
C) <fact10>Right gastroepiploic artery</fact10>
D) <fact11>Left gastroepiploic artery</fact11>
E) <fact12>Common hepatic artery</fact12>

Answer: The <fact4>splenic artery</fact4> is a branch of the <fact5>celiac trunk</fact5>, which is the first major branch of the <fact13>aorta</fact13>. The <fact4>splenic artery</fact4> supplies blood to the <fact14>spleen</fact14> and is not directly connected to the <fact15>gastroduodenal artery</fact15>, <fact10>right gastroepiploic artery</fact10>, <fact11>left gastroepiploic artery</fact11>, or <fact12>common hepatic artery</fact12>. However, the <fact8>left gastric artery</fact8> is a branch of the <fact5>celiac trunk</fact5> and is located close to the <fact4>splenic artery</fact4>. Although the <fact8>left gastric artery</fact8> is not directly affected by the ligation of the <fact4>splenic artery</fact4>, it is possible that the <fact8>left gastric artery</fact8> may be compromised due to the surgical manipulation and trauma to the surrounding tissues. However, this is not a direct consequence of the ligation of the <fact4>splenic artery</fact4>. The <fact9>gastroduodenal artery</fact9> is a branch of the <fact5>celiac trunk</fact5> that supplies blood to the <fact16>duodenum</fact16> and the <fact17>head of the pancreas</fact17>. The <fact9>gastroduodenal artery</fact9> is not directly connected to the <fact4>splenic artery</fact4> and is not affected by the ligation of the <fact4>splenic artery</fact4>. The <fact10>right gastroepiploic artery</fact10> is a branch of the <fact9>gastroduodenal artery</fact9> and is not directly connected to the <fact4>splenic artery</fact4>. The <fact11>left gastroepiploic artery</fact11> is a branch of the <fact4>splenic artery</fact4> and is directly affected by the ligation of the <fact4>splenic artery</fact4>. The <fact12>common hepatic artery</fact12> is a branch of the <fact5>celiac trunk</fact5> that supplies blood to the <fact18>liver</fact18> and is not directly connected to the <fact4>splenic artery</fact4>. Therefore, the correct answer is {D}.

question:
A 55-year-old male visited his primary care physician complaining of chest pain and progressive shortness of breath worsened by exertion. His vital signs were within normal limits. He reports that he worked in a naval shipyard for 10 years during his twenties. A CT scan of his chest shows diffuse thickening of the pleura and a diagnosis of mesothelioma is made. Assuming this diagnosis is correct, which of the following is most likely to also be present in this patient?
A) Pneumothorax
B) Pleural effusion
C) Systemic inflammatory response syndrome
D) Bronchioalveolar carcinoma
E) Bronchiectasis
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>55-year-old male</fact1> visited his primary care physician complaining of <fact2>chest pain and progressive shortness of breath worsened by exertion</fact2>. His vital signs were within normal limits. He reports that he worked in a <fact3>naval shipyard for 10 years during his twenties</fact3>. A <fact4>CT scan of his chest</fact4> shows <fact5>diffuse thickening of the pleura</fact5> and a diagnosis of <fact6>mesothelioma</fact6> is made. Assuming this diagnosis is correct, which of the following is most likely to also be present in this patient? <fact7>key phrases: mesothelioma, pleural thickening</fact7>

Answer: Given the patient's diagnosis of <fact6>mesothelioma</fact6> and the presence of <fact5>diffuse thickening of the pleura</fact5> on the <fact4>CT scan of his chest</fact4>, it is likely that he also has a <fact8>pleural effusion</fact8>. This is because mesothelioma is a type of cancer that originates in the pleura, and pleural effusion is a common complication of this disease. Therefore, the correct answer is {B}.

question:
A healthy 19-year-old man presents to his primary care provider complaining of painless “blisters” in his mouth. He reports that he noticed a white film on his tongue and the sides of his mouth 2 days ago while brushing his teeth. The film was easily brushed off. He also complains of a bitter metallic taste in his mouth but otherwise denies pain, burning, dysphagia, or hoarseness. He is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. He is a competitive swimmer and has had 8 sexual partners in the past year. He intermittently uses barrier protection. On exam, he is well-appearing and in no acute distress. His oral examination demonstrates patches of white pseudomembranes that can be wiped away to reveal erythematous mucosa. A medication with which of the following mechanisms of action is most appropriate in this patient?
A) Disruption of cell membrane permeability
B) Disruption of microtubule formation
C) Inhibition of 14-alpha-demethylase
D) Inhibition of beta-glucan synthase
E) Inhibition of squalene epoxidase
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>healthy 19-year-old man</fact1> presents to his primary care provider complaining of <fact2>painless “blisters” in his mouth</fact2>. He reports that he noticed a <fact3>white film on his tongue and the sides of his mouth</fact3> 2 days ago while brushing his teeth. The film was easily brushed off. He also complains of a <fact4>bitter metallic taste in his mouth</fact4> but otherwise denies <fact5>pain, burning, dysphagia, or hoarseness</fact5>. He is otherwise <fact6>healthy and takes no medications</fact6>. He is a <fact7>competitive swimmer</fact7> and has had <fact8>8 sexual partners in the past year</fact8>. He intermittently uses <fact9>barrier protection</fact9>. On exam, he is <fact10>well-appearing and in no acute distress</fact10>. His oral examination demonstrates <fact11>patches of white pseudomembranes that can be wiped away to reveal erythematous mucosa</fact11>. A medication with which of the following mechanisms of action is most appropriate in this patient? Options: (A) Disruption of cell membrane permeability (B) Disruption of microtubule formation (C) Inhibition of 14-alpha-demethylase (D) Inhibition of beta-glucan synthase (E) Inhibition of squalene epoxidase

Answer: Based on the patient's presentation, the <fact11>painless “blisters” in his mouth</fact11> and the presence of <fact11>patches of white pseudomembranes that can be wiped away to reveal erythematous mucosa</fact11> are indicative of oral candidiasis, also known as thrush. This condition is caused by an overgrowth of the fungus Candida albicans, which is a common opportunistic pathogen that can take advantage of weakened immune systems or mucosal damage. Given the patient's symptoms and oral examination findings, a medication that targets the cell membrane of the fungus is most appropriate. Specifically, <fact6>disruption of cell membrane permeability</fact6> is a mechanism of action that is effective against Candida albicans. Therefore, the most appropriate medication for this patient is one that disrupts cell membrane permeability, which is option {A}.

question:
A 67-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a follow up appointment. He was released from the hospital 1 week ago for an appropriately managed ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI); however, he has not filled any of his prescriptions and did not attend his follow up appointment as scheduled. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and peripheral vascular disease. His temperature is 97.5°F (36.4°C), blood pressure is 167/118 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam is notable for jugular venous distention and bilateral lower extremity pitting edema. Echocardiography demonstrates an ejection fraction of 55%. Which of the following medications will have the greatest mortality benefit in this patient?
A) Atenolol
B) Hydrochlorothiazide
C) Lisinopril
D) Metoprolol succinate
E) Propranolol
answer:

A <fact1>67-year-old man</fact1> presents to his primary care physician for a follow-up appointment. He was released from the hospital 1 week ago for an appropriately managed <fact2>ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)</fact2>; however, he has not filled any of his prescriptions and did not attend his follow-up appointment as scheduled. The patient has a past medical history of <fact3>hypertension</fact3> and <fact4>peripheral vascular disease</fact4>. His <fact5>temperature is 97.5°F (36.4°C)</fact5>, <fact6>blood pressure is 167/118 mmHg</fact6>, <fact7>pulse is 90/min</fact7>, <fact8>respirations are 14/min</fact8>, and <fact9>oxygen saturation is 99% on room air</fact9>. Physical exam is notable for <fact10>jugular venous distention</fact10> and <fact11>bilateral lower extremity pitting edema</fact11>. Echocardiography demonstrates an <fact12>ejection fraction of 55%</fact12>. Which of the following medications will have the greatest mortality benefit in this patient?

Answer: 
Given the patient's history of <fact2>ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)</fact2> and current presentation of <fact6>hypertension</fact6> and <fact11>bilateral lower extremity pitting edema</fact11>, the primary concern is to prevent further cardiovascular events. The <fact12>ejection fraction of 55%</fact12> indicates that the patient has heart failure, which is a significant risk factor for mortality. Among the provided options, <fact3>hypertension</fact3> management is crucial, and the use of an ACE inhibitor such as <D> Lisinopril</D> has been shown to reduce mortality in patients with heart failure. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 25-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider for evaluation of a "painful mass in my left groin." She says that her symptoms began 4 days ago as a painful mass that slowly enlarged, ruptured, and ulcerated. However, she denies fever, chills, dysuria, or hematuria. Three weeks prior to her current symptoms she noted a small, painless ulcer on her labium majorum that resolved after a few days. She admits to having unprotected sex with a male partner a month ago while she was traveling in Southeast Asia. Temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 139/84 mmHg, pulse is 76/min, and respirations are 18/min. Physical examination is significant for left-sided, tender, ulcerative lymph nodes with a dark discoloration. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in this patient's condition?
A) Donovan bodies on Wright-Giemsa stain
B) Gram-negative rods in school of fish formation on Gram stain
C) PCR positive for Chlamydia trachomatis
D) Positive RPR, VDRL, and FTA-ABS
E) Tzanck smear with multinucleated giant cells
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>25-year-old woman</fact1> presents to her primary care provider for evaluation of a "<fact2>painful mass in my left groin</fact2>." She says that her symptoms began <fact3>4 days ago</fact3> as a <fact4>painful mass</fact4> that slowly <fact5>enlarged</fact5>, <fact6>ruptured</fact6>, and <fact7>ulcerated</fact7>. However, she denies <fact8>fever</fact8>, <fact9>chills</fact9>, <fact10>dysuria</fact10>, or <fact11>hematuria</fact11>. Three weeks prior to her current symptoms she noted a <fact12>small, painless ulcer</fact12> on her <fact13>labium majorum</fact13> that resolved after a few days. She admits to having <fact14>unprotected sex</fact14> with a male partner a month ago while she was <fact15>traveling in Southeast Asia</fact15>. <fact16>Temperature is 99°F (37.2°C)</fact16>, <fact17>blood pressure is 139/84 mmHg</fact17>, <fact18>pulse is 76/min</fact18>, and <fact19>respirations are 18/min</fact19>. Physical examination is significant for <fact20>left-sided, tender, ulcerative lymph nodes</fact20> with a <fact21>dark discoloration</fact21>. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in this patient's condition?

Answer: Considering the patient's symptoms of a <fact2>painful mass in my left groin</fact2> that <fact5>enlarged</fact5>, <fact6>ruptured</fact6>, and <fact7>ulcerated</fact7>, along with a <fact12>small, painless ulcer</fact12> on her <fact13>labium majorum</fact13> three weeks prior, this presentation is highly suggestive of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), a sexually transmitted infection caused by certain serovars of Chlamydia trachomatis. The patient's recent travel to <fact15>Southeast Asia</fact15> and history of <fact14>unprotected sex</fact14> further support this diagnosis. Among the options provided, the presence of <fact21>dark discoloration</fact21> in the <fact20>ulcerative lymph nodes</fact20> is most consistent with LGV. Donovan bodies, which are characteristic of LGV, can be identified on a <fact22>Wright-Giemsa stain</fact22> of the affected lymph nodes. Therefore, the correct answer is {A}.

question:
A laboratory primarily involved with studying cellular proofreading mechanisms is investigating the question of whether the ribosome can recognize a mischarged amino acid and still be incorporated into the growing peptide. In order to do so, they biochemically charge a Lys-tRNA with valine instead of lysine and insert the tRNA into the cell. They design an mRNA sequence that contains only codons for lysine. Which of the following will most likely occur?
A) The ribosome will recognize the mischarged tRNA and prevent its incorporation by removing the valine
B) The ribosome will recognize the inappropriately inserted valine residue and terminate protein translation
C) The mischarged tRNA with valine will be incorporated in the codons that specificy for lysine
D) The mischarged tRNA will be degraded by the proteasome
E) The mischarged tRNA will be removed by the lysyl-tRNA synthetase
answer:
Reformatted Question: A laboratory primarily involved with studying cellular proofreading mechanisms is investigating the question of whether the <fact1>ribosome</fact1> can recognize a <fact2>mischarged amino acid</fact2> and still be incorporated into the <fact3>growing peptide</fact3>. In order to do so, they biochemically <fact4>charge a Lys-tRNA with valine instead of lysine</fact4> and <fact5>insert the tRNA into the cell</fact5>. They design an <fact6>mRNA sequence</fact6> that contains only <fact7>codons for lysine</fact7>. Which of the following will most likely occur?

Answer: Evaluating the laboratory's experiment, they are investigating whether the <fact1>ribosome</fact1> can recognize a <fact2>mischarged amino acid</fact2> and still be incorporated into the <fact3>growing peptide</fact3>. To test this, they biochemically <fact4>charge a Lys-tRNA with valine instead of lysine</fact4>, which is a <fact5>mischarged tRNA</fact5>. They then <fact5>insert the tRNA into the cell</fact5> and design an <fact6>mRNA sequence</fact6> that contains only <fact7>codons for lysine</fact7>. Given this setup, the <fact1>ribosome</fact1> will attempt to translate the <fact6>mRNA sequence</fact6> into a <fact3>growing peptide</fact3>. Since the <fact5>mischarged tRNA</fact5> contains valine instead of lysine, it will be incorporated into the <fact3>growing peptide</fact3> in place of lysine. Therefore, the correct answer is {C}.

question:
A 56-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents to his physician with progressive fatigue and new onset muscle cramps. He has had no recent changes to his medication regimen, which includes hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, and amlodipine. His temperature is 98.0°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 174/111 mmHg, pulse is 70/min, respirations are 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient's cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Laboratory values are ordered as seen below.

Serum:
Na+: 138 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
K+: 3.3 mEq/L
HCO3-: 33 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Glucose: 129 mg/dL

What is the most likely underlying etiology of this patient's hypertension?
A) Aldosterone excess
B) Catecholamine-secreting mass
C) Cortisol excess
D) Impaired kidney perfusion
E) Increased peripheral vascular resistance
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>56-year-old man</fact1> with a <fact2>history of hypertension</fact2> presents to his physician with <fact3>progressive fatigue</fact3> and new onset <fact4>muscle cramps</fact4>. He has had no recent changes to his <fact5>medication regimen</fact5>, which includes <fact6>hydrochlorothiazide</fact6>, <fact7>lisinopril</fact7>, and <fact8>amlodipine</fact8>. His <fact9>temperature is 98.0°F (36.7°C)</fact9>, <fact10>blood pressure is 174/111 mmHg</fact10>, <fact11>pulse is 70/min</fact11>, <fact12>respirations are 12/min</fact12>, and <fact13>oxygen saturation is 98% on room air</fact13>. The patient's <fact14>cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable</fact14>. Laboratory values are ordered as seen below.

Serum:
Na+: <fact15>138 mEq/L</fact15>
Cl-: <fact16>100 mEq/L</fact16>
K+: <fact17>3.3 mEq/L</fact17>
HCO3-: <fact18>33 mEq/L</fact18>
BUN: <fact19>20 mg/dL</fact19>
Glucose: <fact20>129 mg/dL</fact20>

What is the most likely underlying etiology of this patient's <fact21>hypertension</fact21>?

Answer: A) Aldosterone excess
